The number **π** ([/ˈpaɪ/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English")) is a
[mathematical constant](/wiki/Mathematical_constant "Mathematical constant").
Originally defined as the [ratio](/wiki/Ratio "Ratio") of a
[circle](/wiki/Circle "Circle")'s [circumference](/wiki/Circumference
"Circumference") to its [diameter](/wiki/Diameter "Diameter"), it now has
various equivalent definitions and appears in many formulas in all areas of
[mathematics](/wiki/Mathematics "Mathematics") and [physics](/wiki/Physics
"Physics"). It is approximately equal to 3.14159. It has been represented by
the Greek letter "π" since the mid-18th century, though it is also sometimes
spelled out as "**pi** ".

Being an [irrational number](/wiki/Irrational_number "Irrational number"), π
cannot be expressed exactly as a [common fraction](/wiki/Common_fraction
"Common fraction") (equivalently, its [decimal
representation](/wiki/Decimal_representation "Decimal representation") never
ends and never [settles into a permanent repeating
pattern](/wiki/Repeating_decimal "Repeating decimal")). Still, fractions such
as 22/7 and other rational numbers are commonly used to
[approximate](/wiki/Approximations_of_%CF%80 "Approximations of π") π. The
digits appear to be [randomly distributed](/wiki/Random_sequence "Random
sequence"). In particular, the digit sequence of π is conjectured to satisfy a
[specific kind of statistical randomness](/wiki/Normal_number "Normal
number"), but to date no proof of this has been discovered. Also, π is a
[transcendental number](/wiki/Transcendental_number "Transcendental number");
that is, a number that is not the [root](/wiki/Root_of_a_polynomial "Root of a
polynomial") of any non-zero [polynomial](/wiki/Polynomial "Polynomial")
having [rational](/wiki/Rational_number "Rational number")
[coefficients](/wiki/Coefficient "Coefficient"). This transcendence of π
implies that it is impossible to solve the ancient challenge of [squaring the
circle](/wiki/Squaring_the_circle "Squaring the circle") with a [compass and
straightedge](/wiki/Compass-and-straightedge_construction "Compass-and-
straightedge construction").

Ancient civilizations required fairly accurate computed values for π for
practical reasons. It was calculated to seven digits, using geometrical
techniques, in [Chinese
mathematics](/wiki/History_of_mathematics#Chinese_mathematics "History of
mathematics"), and to about five digits in [Indian
mathematics](/wiki/History_of_mathematics#Indian_mathematics "History of
mathematics") in the 5th century AD. The historically first exact formula for
π, based on [infinite series](/wiki/Series_\(mathematics\) "Series
\(mathematics\)"), was not available until a millennium later, when in the
14th century the [Madhava–Leibniz series](/wiki/Leibniz_formula_for_pi
"Leibniz formula for pi") was discovered in Indian mathematics.[1][2] In the
20th and 21st centuries, mathematicians and [computer
scientists](/wiki/Computer_science "Computer science") discovered new
approaches that, when combined with increasing computational power, extended
the decimal representation of π to many trillions of digits after the decimal
point.[3] Practically all scientific applications require no more than a few
hundred digits of π, and many substantially fewer, so the primary motivation
for these computations is the quest to find more efficient algorithms for
calculating lengthy numeric series, as well as the desire to break
records.[4][5] The extensive calculations involved have also been used to test
[supercomputers](/wiki/Supercomputer "Supercomputer") and high-precision
multiplication [algorithms](/wiki/Algorithms "Algorithms").

Because its most elementary definition relates to the circle, π is found in
many formulae in [trigonometry](/wiki/Trigonometry "Trigonometry") and
[geometry](/wiki/Geometry "Geometry"), especially those concerning circles,
ellipses, and spheres. In more modern [mathematical
analysis](/wiki/Mathematical_analysis "Mathematical analysis"), the number is
instead defined using the spectral properties of the [real
number](/wiki/Real_number "Real number") system, as an
[eigenvalue](/wiki/Eigenvalue "Eigenvalue") or a
[period](/wiki/Periodic_function "Periodic function"), without any reference
to geometry. It appears therefore in areas of mathematics and the sciences
having little to do with the geometry of circles, such as [number
theory](/wiki/Number_theory "Number theory") and [statistics](/wiki/Statistics
"Statistics"), as well as in almost all areas of [physics](/wiki/Physics
"Physics"). The ubiquity of π makes it one of the most widely known
mathematical constants both inside and outside the scientific community;
several books devoted to it have been published, the number is celebrated on
[Pi Day](/wiki/Pi_Day "Pi Day"), and record-setting calculations of the digits
of π often result in news headlines. Attempts to memorize the value of π with
increasing precision have led to records of over 70,000 digits.

## Fundamentals

### Name

The symbol used by mathematicians to represent the ratio of a circle's
circumference to its diameter is the lowercase [Greek letter
π](/wiki/Pi_\(letter\) "Pi \(letter\)"), sometimes spelled out as _pi,_ and
derived from the first letter of the Greek word _perimetros,_ meaning
circumference.[6] In English, π is [pronounced as
"pie"](/wiki/English_pronunciation_of_Greek_letters "English pronunciation of
Greek letters") ([/paɪ/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English"),
[_paɪ_](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling
key")).[7] In mathematical use, the lowercase letter π (or π in [sans-
serif](/wiki/Sans-serif "Sans-serif") font) is distinguished from its
capitalized and enlarged counterpart ∏, which denotes a [product of a
sequence](/wiki/Product_of_a_sequence "Product of a sequence"), analogous to
how ∑ denotes [summation](/wiki/Summation "Summation").

The choice of the symbol π is discussed in the section _Adoption of the symbol
π_.

### Definition

[![A diagram of a circle, with the width labeled as diameter, and the
perimeter labeled as
circumference](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Pi_eq_C_over_d.svg/220px-
Pi_eq_C_over_d.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Pi_eq_C_over_d.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Pi_eq_C_over_d.svg "Enlarge")

The circumference of a circle is slightly more than three times as long as its
diameter. The exact ratio is called π.

π is commonly defined as the [ratio](/wiki/Ratio "Ratio") of a
[circle](/wiki/Circle "Circle")'s [circumference](/wiki/Circumference
"Circumference") _C_ to its [diameter](/wiki/Diameter "Diameter") _d_ :[8]

     π = C d {\displaystyle \pi ={\frac {C}{d}}} ![\\pi ={\\frac {C}{d}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/d3ffc6970dda2e60597854f14e2ac1e13a25a5cf)

The ratio _C_ /_d_ is constant, regardless of the circle's size. For example,
if a circle has twice the diameter of another circle it will also have twice
the circumference, preserving the ratio _C_ /_d_. This definition of π
implicitly makes use of [flat (Euclidean) geometry](/wiki/Euclidean_geometry
"Euclidean geometry"); although the notion of a circle can be extended to any
[curved (non-Euclidean) geometry](/wiki/Non-Euclidean_geometry "Non-Euclidean
geometry"), these new circles will no longer satisfy the formula π = _C_
/_d_.[8]

Here, the circumference of a circle is the [arc length](/wiki/Arc_length "Arc
length") around the perimeter of the circle, a quantity which can be formally
defined independently of geometry using [limits](/wiki/Limit_\(mathematics\)
"Limit \(mathematics\)"), a concept in [calculus](/wiki/Calculus
"Calculus").[9] For example, one may compute directly the arc length of the
top half of the unit circle given in [Cartesian
coordinates](/wiki/Cartesian_coordinates "Cartesian coordinates") by _x_ 2 \+
_y_ 2 = 1, as the [integral](/wiki/Integral "Integral"):[10]

     π = ∫ − 1 1 d x 1 − x 2 . {\displaystyle \pi =\int _{-1}^{1}{\frac {dx}{\sqrt {1-x^{2}}}}.} ![\\pi =\\int _{-1}^{1}{\\frac {dx}{\\sqrt {1-x^{2}}}}.](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/50725fce8b20701f737a6ecc57aff4b8969107c4)

An integral such as this was adopted as the definition of π by [Karl
Weierstrass](/wiki/Karl_Weierstrass "Karl Weierstrass"), who defined it
directly as an integral in 1841.[11]

Definitions of π such as these that rely on a notion of circumference, and
hence implicitly on concepts of the [integral
calculus](/wiki/Integral_calculus "Integral calculus"), are no longer common
in the literature. Remmert (1991) explains that this is because in many modern
treatments of calculus, [differential calculus](/wiki/Differential_calculus
"Differential calculus") typically precedes integral calculus in the
university curriculum, so it is desirable to have a definition of π that does
not rely on the latter. One such definition, due to [Richard
Baltzer](/w/index.php?title=Richard_Baltzer&action=edit&redlink=1 "Richard
Baltzer \(page does not exist\)"),[12] and popularized by [Edmund
Landau](/wiki/Edmund_Landau "Edmund Landau"),[13] is the following: π is twice
the smallest positive number at which the [cosine function](/wiki/Cosine
"Cosine") equals 0.[8][10][14] The cosine can be defined independently of
geometry as a [power series](/wiki/Power_series "Power series"),[15] or as the
solution of a [differential equation](/wiki/Differential_equation
"Differential equation").[14]

In a similar spirit, π can be defined instead using properties of the [complex
exponential](/wiki/Complex_exponential "Complex exponential"), exp(_z_), of a
[complex](/wiki/Complex_number "Complex number") variable _z_. Like the
cosine, the complex exponential can be defined in one of several ways. The set
of complex numbers at which exp(_z_) is equal to one is then an (imaginary)
arithmetic progression of the form:

     { … , − 2 π i , 0 , 2 π i , 4 π i , … } = { 2 π k i ∣ k ∈ Z } {\displaystyle \\{\dots ,-2\pi i,0,2\pi i,4\pi i,\dots \\}=\\{2\pi ki\mid k\in \mathbb {Z} \\}} ![{\\displaystyle \\{\\dots ,-2\\pi i,0,2\\pi i,4\\pi i,\\dots \\}=\\{2\\pi ki\\mid k\\in \\mathbb {Z} \\}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/9411506ae82c49d1b868a47ce5dea04adf234cba)

and there is a unique positive real number π with this property.[10][16] A
more abstract variation on the same idea, making use of sophisticated
mathematical concepts of [topology](/wiki/Topology "Topology") and
[algebra](/wiki/Algebra "Algebra"), is the following theorem:[17] there is a
unique ([up to](/wiki/Up_to "Up to") [automorphism](/wiki/Automorphism
"Automorphism")) [continuous](/wiki/Continuous_function "Continuous function")
[isomorphism](/wiki/Isomorphism "Isomorphism") from the
[group](/wiki/Group_\(mathematics\) "Group \(mathematics\)") **R** /**Z** of
real numbers under addition [modulo](/wiki/Quotient_group "Quotient group")
integers (the [circle group](/wiki/Circle_group "Circle group")) onto the
multiplicative group of [complex numbers](/wiki/Complex_numbers "Complex
numbers") of [absolute value](/wiki/Absolute_value "Absolute value") one. The
number π is then defined as half the magnitude of the derivative of this
homomorphism.[18]

A circle encloses the largest area that can be attained within a given
perimeter. Thus the number π is also characterized as the best constant in the
[isoperimetric inequality](/wiki/Isoperimetric_inequality "Isoperimetric
inequality") (times one-fourth). There are many other, closely related, ways
in which π appears as an [eigenvalue](/wiki/Eigenvalue "Eigenvalue") of some
geometrical or physical process; see below.

### Irrationality and normality

π is an [irrational number](/wiki/Irrational_number "Irrational number"),
meaning that it cannot be written as the [ratio of two
integers](/wiki/Rational_number "Rational number") (fractions such as 22/7 are
commonly used to approximate π, but no [common fraction](/wiki/Common_fraction
"Common fraction") (ratio of whole numbers) can be its exact value).[19]
Because π is irrational, it has an infinite number of digits in its [decimal
representation](/wiki/Decimal_representation "Decimal representation"), and it
does not settle into an infinitely [repeating pattern](/wiki/Repeating_decimal
"Repeating decimal") of digits. There are several [proofs that π is
irrational](/wiki/Proof_that_%CF%80_is_irrational "Proof that π is
irrational"); they generally require calculus and rely on the [reductio ad
absurdum](/wiki/Reductio_ad_absurdum "Reductio ad absurdum") technique. The
degree to which π can be approximated by [rational
numbers](/wiki/Rational_number "Rational number") (called the [irrationality
measure](/wiki/Irrationality_measure "Irrationality measure")) is not
precisely known; estimates have established that the irrationality measure is
larger than the measure of _e_ or ln(2) but smaller than the measure of
[Liouville numbers](/wiki/Liouville_number "Liouville number").[20]

The digits of π have no apparent pattern and have passed tests for
[statistical randomness](/wiki/Statistical_randomness "Statistical
randomness"), including tests for [normality](/wiki/Normal_number "Normal
number"); a number of infinite length is called normal when all possible
sequences of digits (of any given length) appear equally often.[21] The
conjecture that π is [normal](/wiki/Normal_number "Normal number") has not
been proven or disproven.[21]

Since the advent of computers, a large number of digits of π have been
available on which to perform statistical analysis. [Yasumasa
Kanada](/wiki/Yasumasa_Kanada "Yasumasa Kanada") has performed detailed
statistical analyses on the decimal digits of π and found them consistent with
normality; for example, the frequencies of the ten digits 0 to 9 were
subjected to [statistical significance
tests](/wiki/Statistical_significance_test "Statistical significance test"),
and no evidence of a pattern was found.[22] Any random sequence of digits
contains arbitrarily long subsequences that appear non-random, by the
[infinite monkey theorem](/wiki/Infinite_monkey_theorem "Infinite monkey
theorem"). Thus, because the sequence of π's digits passes statistical tests
for randomness, it contains some sequences of digits that may appear non-
random, such as a [sequence of six consecutive 9s](/wiki/Six_nines_in_pi "Six
nines in pi") that begins at the 762nd decimal place of the decimal
representation of π.[23] This is also called the "Feynman point" in
[mathematical folklore](/wiki/Mathematical_folklore "Mathematical folklore"),
after [Richard Feynman](/wiki/Richard_Feynman "Richard Feynman"), although no
connection to Feynman is known.

### Transcendence

[![A diagram of a square and circle, both with identical area; the length of
the side of the square is the square root of
pi](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Squaring_the_circle.svg/220px-
Squaring_the_circle.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Squaring_the_circle.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Squaring_the_circle.svg "Enlarge")

Because π is a [transcendental number](/wiki/Transcendental_number
"Transcendental number"), [squaring the circle](/wiki/Squaring_the_circle
"Squaring the circle") is not possible in a finite number of steps using the
classical tools of [compass and straightedge](/wiki/Compass-and-
straightedge_construction "Compass-and-straightedge construction").

In addition to being irrational, more strongly π is a [transcendental
number](/wiki/Transcendental_number "Transcendental number"), which means that
it is not the [solution](/wiki/Solution_\(equation\) "Solution \(equation\)")
of any non-constant [polynomial equation](/wiki/Polynomial_equation
"Polynomial equation") with [rational](/wiki/Rational_number "Rational
number") coefficients, such as _x_ 5/120 − _x_ 3/6 \+ _x_ = 0.[24][25]

The transcendence of π has two important consequences: First, π cannot be
expressed using any finite combination of rational numbers and square roots or
[_n_ -th roots](/wiki/N-th_root "N-th root") such as 3√31 or √10. Second,
since no transcendental number can be [constructed](/wiki/Constructible_number
"Constructible number") with [compass and straightedge](/wiki/Compass-and-
straightedge_construction "Compass-and-straightedge construction"), it is not
possible to "[square the circle](/wiki/Squaring_the_circle "Squaring the
circle")". In other words, it is impossible to construct, using compass and
straightedge alone, a square whose area is exactly equal to the area of a
given circle.[26] Squaring a circle was one of the important geometry problems
of the [classical antiquity](/wiki/Classical_antiquity "Classical
antiquity").[27] Amateur mathematicians in modern times have sometimes
attempted to square the circle and sometimes claim success despite the fact
that it is mathematically impossible.[28]

### Continued fractions

[![A photograph of the Greek letter pi, created as a large stone mosaic
embedded in the
ground.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Matheon2.jpg/220px-
Matheon2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Matheon2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Matheon2.jpg "Enlarge")

The constant π is represented in this [mosaic](/wiki/Mosaic "Mosaic") outside
the Mathematics Building at the [Technical University of
Berlin](/wiki/Technical_University_of_Berlin "Technical University of
Berlin").

Like all irrational numbers, π cannot be represented as a [common
fraction](/wiki/Common_fraction "Common fraction") (also known as a
[simple](/wiki/Simple_fractions "Simple fractions") or [vulgar
fraction](/wiki/Vulgar_fraction "Vulgar fraction")), by the very definition of
"irrational number" (that is, "not a rational number"). But every irrational
number, including π, can be represented by an infinite series of nested
fractions, called a [continued fraction](/wiki/Continued_fraction "Continued
fraction"):

     π = 3 + 1 7 + 1 15 + 1 1 + 1 292 + 1 1 + 1 1 + 1 1 + ⋱ {\displaystyle \pi =3+\textstyle {\cfrac {1}{7+\textstyle {\cfrac {1}{15+\textstyle {\cfrac {1}{1+\textstyle {\cfrac {1}{292+\textstyle {\cfrac {1}{1+\textstyle {\cfrac {1}{1+\textstyle {\cfrac {1}{1+\ddots }}}}}}}}}}}}}}} ![{\\displaystyle \\pi =3+\\textstyle {\\cfrac {1}{7+\\textstyle {\\cfrac {1}{15+\\textstyle {\\cfrac {1}{1+\\textstyle {\\cfrac {1}{292+\\textstyle {\\cfrac {1}{1+\\textstyle {\\cfrac {1}{1+\\textstyle {\\cfrac {1}{1+\\ddots }}}}}}}}}}}}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/e294255007892e9424e6d3f49183cad6b133bbcf)

Truncating the continued fraction at any point yields a rational approximation
for π; the first four of these are 3, 22/7, 333/106, and 355/113. These
numbers are among the most well-known and widely used historical
approximations of the constant. Each approximation generated in this way is a
best rational approximation; that is, each is closer to π than any other
fraction with the same or a smaller denominator.[29] Because π is known to be
transcendental, it is by definition not [algebraic](/wiki/Algebraic_number
"Algebraic number") and so cannot be a [quadratic
irrational](/wiki/Quadratic_irrational "Quadratic irrational"). Therefore, π
cannot have a [periodic continued fraction](/wiki/Periodic_continued_fraction
"Periodic continued fraction"). Although the simple continued fraction for π
(shown above) also does not exhibit any other obvious pattern,[30]
mathematicians have discovered several [generalized continued
fractions](/wiki/Generalized_continued_fraction "Generalized continued
fraction") that do, such as:[31]

     π = 4 1 + 1 2 2 + 3 2 2 + 5 2 2 + 7 2 2 + 9 2 2 + ⋱ = 3 + 1 2 6 + 3 2 6 + 5 2 6 + 7 2 6 + 9 2 6 + ⋱ = 4 1 + 1 2 3 + 2 2 5 + 3 2 7 + 4 2 9 + ⋱ {\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}\pi &=\textstyle {\cfrac {4}{1+\textstyle {\cfrac {1^{2}}{2+\textstyle {\cfrac {3^{2}}{2+\textstyle {\cfrac {5^{2}}{2+\textstyle {\cfrac {7^{2}}{2+\textstyle {\cfrac {9^{2}}{2+\ddots }}}}}}}}}}}}=3+\textstyle {\cfrac {1^{2}}{6+\textstyle {\cfrac {3^{2}}{6+\textstyle {\cfrac {5^{2}}{6+\textstyle {\cfrac {7^{2}}{6+\textstyle {\cfrac {9^{2}}{6+\ddots }}}}}}}}}}\\\\[8pt]&=\textstyle {\cfrac {4}{1+\textstyle {\cfrac {1^{2}}{3+\textstyle {\cfrac {2^{2}}{5+\textstyle {\cfrac {3^{2}}{7+\textstyle {\cfrac {4^{2}}{9+\ddots }}}}}}}}}}\end{aligned}}} ![{\\displaystyle {\\begin{aligned}\\pi &=\\textstyle {\\cfrac {4}{1+\\textstyle {\\cfrac {1^{2}}{2+\\textstyle {\\cfrac {3^{2}}{2+\\textstyle {\\cfrac {5^{2}}{2+\\textstyle {\\cfrac {7^{2}}{2+\\textstyle {\\cfrac {9^{2}}{2+\\ddots }}}}}}}}}}}}=3+\\textstyle {\\cfrac {1^{2}}{6+\\textstyle {\\cfrac {3^{2}}{6+\\textstyle {\\cfrac {5^{2}}{6+\\textstyle {\\cfrac {7^{2}}{6+\\textstyle {\\cfrac {9^{2}}{6+\\ddots }}}}}}}}}}\\\\\[8pt\]&=\\textstyle {\\cfrac {4}{1+\\textstyle {\\cfrac {1^{2}}{3+\\textstyle {\\cfrac {2^{2}}{5+\\textstyle {\\cfrac {3^{2}}{7+\\textstyle {\\cfrac {4^{2}}{9+\\ddots }}}}}}}}}}\\end{aligned}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/1fae3895746dc6b6022f46ada2915a397abe575d)

  * **Integers** : [3](/wiki/3 "3")
