### Complex numbers and Euler's identity

[![A diagram of a unit circle centered at the origin in the complex plane,
including a ray from the center of the circle to its edge, with the triangle
legs labeled with sine and cosine
functions.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Euler%27s_formula.svg/220px-
Euler%27s_formula.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Euler%27s_formula.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Euler%27s_formula.svg "Enlarge")

The association between imaginary powers of the number _e_ and
[points](/wiki/Point_\(geometry\) "Point \(geometry\)") on the [unit
circle](/wiki/Unit_circle "Unit circle") centered at the
[origin](/wiki/Origin_\(mathematics\) "Origin \(mathematics\)") in the
[complex plane](/wiki/Complex_plane "Complex plane") given by [Euler's
formula](/wiki/Euler%27s_formula "Euler's formula").

Any [complex number](/wiki/Complex_number "Complex number"), say _z_ , can be
expressed using a pair of [real numbers](/wiki/Real_number "Real number"). In
the [polar coordinate system](/wiki/Polar_coordinate_system#Complex_numbers
"Polar coordinate system"), one number ([radius](/wiki/Radius "Radius") or
_r_) is used to represent _z_ 's distance from the
[origin](/wiki/Origin_\(mathematics\) "Origin \(mathematics\)") of the
[complex plane](/wiki/Complex_plane "Complex plane") and the other (angle or
φ) to represent a counter-clockwise [rotation](/wiki/Rotation "Rotation") from
the positive real line as follows:[35]

     z = r ⋅ ( cos ⁡ φ + i sin ⁡ φ ) , {\displaystyle z=r\cdot (\cos \varphi +i\sin \varphi ),} ![z=r\\cdot \(\\cos \\varphi +i\\sin \\varphi \),](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/8e93279bb31b398ca08d16fb9d764fd1214174ab)

where _i_ is the [imaginary unit](/wiki/Imaginary_unit "Imaginary unit")
satisfying _i_ 2 = −1. The frequent appearance of π in [complex
analysis](/wiki/Complex_analysis "Complex analysis") can be related to the
behavior of the [exponential function](/wiki/Exponential_function "Exponential
function") of a complex variable, described by [Euler's
formula](/wiki/Euler%27s_formula "Euler's formula"):[36]

     e i φ = cos ⁡ φ + i sin ⁡ φ , {\displaystyle e^{i\varphi }=\cos \varphi +i\sin \varphi ,} ![e^{i\\varphi }=\\cos \\varphi +i\\sin \\varphi ,](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/3b85e2656dda51f900210b347fb30b65d3a26f11)

where [the constant _e_](/wiki/E_\(mathematical_constant\) "E \(mathematical
constant\)") is the base of the [natural logarithm](/wiki/Natural_logarithm
"Natural logarithm"). This formula establishes a correspondence between
imaginary powers of _e_ and points on the [unit circle](/wiki/Unit_circle
"Unit circle") centered at the origin of the complex plane. Setting _φ_ = π in
Euler's formula results in [Euler's identity](/wiki/Euler%27s_identity
"Euler's identity"), celebrated by mathematicians because it contains the five
most important mathematical constants:[36][37]

     e i π + 1 = 0. {\displaystyle e^{i\pi }+1=0.} ![e^{i\\pi }+1=0.](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/e76caf050d8bc37cd2350c40517face26de5ecb7)

There are _n_ different [complex numbers](/wiki/Complex_number "Complex
number") _z_ satisfying _z_ _n_ = 1, and these are called the "_n_ -th [roots
of unity](/wiki/Root_of_unity "Root of unity")".[38] They are given by this
formula:

     e 2 π i k / n ( k = 0 , 1 , 2 , … , n − 1 ) . {\displaystyle e^{2\pi ik/n}\qquad (k=0,1,2,\dots ,n-1).} ![e^{2\\pi ik/n}\\qquad \(k=0,1,2,\\dots ,n-1\).](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/c74d8393eb2cf4d7a3e5ef0dd9ab50a9fe58389f)

## History

Main article: [Approximations of π](/wiki/Approximations_of_%CF%80
"Approximations of π")

See also: [Chronology of computation of
π](/wiki/Chronology_of_computation_of_%CF%80 "Chronology of computation of π")

### Antiquity

The best known approximations to π dating [before the Common
Era](/wiki/1st_millennium_BC "1st millennium BC") were accurate to two decimal
places; this was improved upon in [Chinese
mathematics](/wiki/Chinese_mathematics "Chinese mathematics") in particular by
the mid first millennium, to an accuracy of seven decimal places. After this,
no further progress was made until the late medieval period.

Some Egyptologists[39] have claimed that the [ancient
Egyptians](/wiki/Ancient_Egypt "Ancient Egypt") used an approximation of π as
22/7 from as early as the [Old Kingdom](/wiki/Old_Kingdom "Old Kingdom").[40]
This claim has met with skepticism.[41][42][43][44]

The earliest written approximations of π are found in
[Egypt](/wiki/Ancient_Egypt "Ancient Egypt") and [Babylon](/wiki/Babylon
"Babylon"), both within one percent of the true value. In Babylon, a [clay
tablet](/wiki/Clay_tablet "Clay tablet") dated 1900–1600 BC has a geometrical
statement that, by implication, treats π as 25/8 = 3.125.[45] In Egypt, the
[Rhind Papyrus](/wiki/Rhind_Papyrus "Rhind Papyrus"), dated around 1650 BC but
copied from a document dated to 1850 BC, has a formula for the area of a
circle that treats π as (16/9)2 ≈ 3.1605.[45]

Astronomical calculations in the _[Shatapatha
Brahmana](/wiki/Shatapatha_Brahmana "Shatapatha Brahmana")_ (ca. 4th century
BC) use a fractional approximation of 339/108 ≈ 3.139 (an accuracy of
9×10−4).[46] Other Indian sources by about 150 BC treat π as √10 ≈ 3.1622.[47]

### Polygon approximation era

[![diagram of a hexagon and pentagon circumscribed outside a
circle](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Archimedes_pi.svg/350px-
Archimedes_pi.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Archimedes_pi.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Archimedes_pi.svg "Enlarge")

π can be estimated by computing the perimeters of circumscribed and inscribed
polygons.

The first recorded algorithm for rigorously calculating the value of π was a
geometrical approach using polygons, devised around 250 BC by the Greek
mathematician [Archimedes](/wiki/Archimedes "Archimedes").[48] This polygonal
algorithm dominated for over 1,000 years, and as a result π is sometimes
referred to as "Archimedes' constant".[49] Archimedes computed upper and lower
bounds of π by drawing a regular hexagon inside and outside a circle, and
successively doubling the number of sides until he reached a 96-sided regular
polygon. By calculating the perimeters of these polygons, he proved that
223/71 < π < 22/7 (that is 3.1408 < π < 3.1429).[50] Archimedes' upper bound
of 22/7 may have led to a widespread popular belief that π is equal to
22/7.[51] Around 150 AD, Greek-Roman scientist [Ptolemy](/wiki/Ptolemy
"Ptolemy"), in his _[Almagest](/wiki/Almagest "Almagest")_ , gave a value for
π of 3.1416, which he may have obtained from Archimedes or from [Apollonius of
Perga](/wiki/Apollonius_of_Perga "Apollonius of Perga").[52] Mathematicians
using polygonal algorithms reached 39 digits of π in 1630, a record only
broken in 1699 when infinite series were used to reach 71 digits.[53]

[![A painting of a man
studying](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Archimedes_by_Giuseppe_Nogari.png/170px-
Archimedes_by_Giuseppe_Nogari.png)](/wiki/File:Archimedes_by_Giuseppe_Nogari.png)

[](/wiki/File:Archimedes_by_Giuseppe_Nogari.png "Enlarge")

[Archimedes](/wiki/Archimedes "Archimedes") developed the polygonal approach
to approximating π.

In [ancient China](/wiki/Ancient_China "Ancient China"), values for π included
3.1547 (around 1 AD), √10 (100 AD, approximately 3.1623), and 142/45 (3rd
century, approximately 3.1556).[54] Around 265 AD, the [Wei
Kingdom](/wiki/Cao_Wei "Cao Wei") mathematician [Liu Hui](/wiki/Liu_Hui "Liu
Hui") created a [polygon-based iterative
algorithm](/wiki/Liu_Hui%27s_%CF%80_algorithm "Liu Hui's π algorithm") and
used it with a 3,072-sided polygon to obtain a value of π of 3.1416.[55][56]
Liu later invented a faster method of calculating π and obtained a value of
3.14 with a 96-sided polygon, by taking advantage of the fact that the
differences in area of successive polygons form a geometric series with a
factor of 4.[55] The Chinese mathematician [Zu Chongzhi](/wiki/Zu_Chongzhi "Zu
Chongzhi"), around 480 AD, calculated that π ≈ 355/113 (a fraction that goes
by the name _[Milü](/wiki/Mil%C3%BC "Milü")_ in Chinese), using [Liu Hui's
algorithm](/wiki/Liu_Hui%27s_%CF%80_algorithm "Liu Hui's π algorithm") applied
to a 12,288-sided polygon. With a correct value for its seven first decimal
digits, this value of 3.141592920... remained the most accurate approximation
of π available for the next 800 years.[57]

The Indian astronomer [Aryabhata](/wiki/Aryabhata "Aryabhata") used a value of
3.1416 in his _[Āryabhaṭīya](/wiki/%C4%80ryabha%E1%B9%AD%C4%ABya
"Āryabhaṭīya")_ (499 AD).[58] [Fibonacci](/wiki/Fibonacci "Fibonacci") in c.
1220 computed 3.1418 using a polygonal method, independent of Archimedes.[59]
Italian author [Dante](/wiki/Dante "Dante") apparently employed the value
3+√2/10 ≈ 3.14142.[59]

The Persian astronomer [Jamshīd al-
Kāshī](/wiki/Jamsh%C4%ABd_al-K%C4%81sh%C4%AB "Jamshīd al-Kāshī") produced 9
sexagesimal digits, roughly the equivalent of 16 decimal digits, in 1424 using
a polygon with 3×228 sides,[60][61] which stood as the world record for about
180 years.[62] French mathematician [François
Viète](/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois_Vi%C3%A8te "François Viète") in 1579 achieved 9
digits with a polygon of 3×217 sides.[62] Flemish mathematician [Adriaan van
Roomen](/wiki/Adriaan_van_Roomen "Adriaan van Roomen") arrived at 15 decimal
places in 1593.[62] In 1596, Dutch mathematician [Ludolph van
Ceulen](/wiki/Ludolph_van_Ceulen "Ludolph van Ceulen") reached 20 digits, a
record he later increased to 35 digits (as a result, π was called the
"Ludolphian number" in Germany until the early 20th century).[63] Dutch
scientist [Willebrord Snellius](/wiki/Willebrord_Snellius "Willebrord
Snellius") reached 34 digits in 1621,[64] and Austrian astronomer [Christoph
Grienberger](/wiki/Christoph_Grienberger "Christoph Grienberger") arrived at
38 digits in 1630 using 1040 sides,[65] which remains the most accurate
approximation manually achieved using polygonal algorithms.[64]

### Infinite series

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Comparison_pi_infinite_series.svg/300px-
Comparison_pi_infinite_series.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Comparison_pi_infinite_series.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Comparison_pi_infinite_series.svg "Enlarge")

Comparison of the convergence of several historical infinite series for π. _S
n_ is the approximation after taking _n_ terms. Each subsequent subplot
magnifies the shaded area horizontally by 10 times. [(click for
detail)](/wiki/File:Comparison_pi_infinite_series.svg "File:Comparison pi
infinite series.svg")

The calculation of π was revolutionized by the development of [infinite
series](/wiki/Infinite_series "Infinite series") techniques in the 16th and
17th centuries. An infinite series is the sum of the terms of an infinite
[sequence](/wiki/Sequence_\(mathematics\) "Sequence \(mathematics\)").[66]
Infinite series allowed mathematicians to compute π with much greater
precision than [Archimedes](/wiki/Archimedes "Archimedes") and others who used
geometrical techniques.[66] Although infinite series were exploited for π most
notably by European mathematicians such as [James
Gregory](/wiki/James_Gregory_\(mathematician\) "James Gregory
\(mathematician\)") and [Gottfried Wilhelm
Leibniz](/wiki/Gottfried_Wilhelm_Leibniz "Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz"), the
approach was first discovered in [India](/wiki/India "India") sometime between
1400 and 1500 AD.[67] The first written description of an infinite series that
could be used to compute π was laid out in Sanskrit verse by Indian astronomer
[Nilakantha Somayaji](/wiki/Nilakantha_Somayaji "Nilakantha Somayaji") in his
_[Tantrasamgraha](/wiki/Tantrasamgraha "Tantrasamgraha")_ , around 1500
AD.[68] The series are presented without proof, but proofs are presented in a
later Indian work, _[Yuktibhāṣā](/wiki/Yuktibh%C4%81%E1%B9%A3%C4%81
"Yuktibhāṣā")_ , from around 1530 AD. Nilakantha attributes the series to an
earlier Indian mathematician, [Madhava of
Sangamagrama](/wiki/Madhava_of_Sangamagrama "Madhava of Sangamagrama"), who
lived c. 1350 – c. 1425.[68] Several infinite series are described, including
series for sine, tangent, and cosine, which are now referred to as the
[Madhava series](/wiki/Madhava_series "Madhava series") or [Gregory–Leibniz
series](/wiki/Leibniz_formula_for_%CF%80 "Leibniz formula for π").[68] Madhava
used infinite series to estimate π to 11 digits around 1400, but that value
was improved on around 1430 by the Persian mathematician [Jamshīd al-
Kāshī](/wiki/Jamsh%C4%ABd_al-K%C4%81sh%C4%AB "Jamshīd al-Kāshī"), using a
polygonal algorithm.[69]

[![A formal portrait of a man, with long
hair](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/GodfreyKneller-
IsaacNewton-1689.jpg/170px-GodfreyKneller-
IsaacNewton-1689.jpg)](/wiki/File:GodfreyKneller-IsaacNewton-1689.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:GodfreyKneller-IsaacNewton-1689.jpg "Enlarge")

[Isaac Newton](/wiki/Isaac_Newton "Isaac Newton") used [infinite
series](/wiki/Infinite_series "Infinite series") to compute π to 15 digits,
later writing "I am ashamed to tell you to how many figures I carried these
computations".[70]

The [first infinite sequence discovered in
Europe](/wiki/Vi%C3%A8te%27s_formula "Viète's formula") was an [infinite
product](/wiki/Infinite_product "Infinite product") (rather than an [infinite
sum](/wiki/Infinite_sum "Infinite sum"), which are more typically used in π
calculations) found by French mathematician [François
Viète](/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois_Vi%C3%A8te "François Viète") in 1593:[71][72][73]

     2 π = 2 2 ⋅ 2 + 2 2 ⋅ 2 + 2 + 2 2 ⋯ {\displaystyle {\frac {2}{\pi }}={\frac {\sqrt {2}}{2}}\cdot {\frac {\sqrt {2+{\sqrt {2}}}}{2}}\cdot {\frac {\sqrt {2+{\sqrt {2+{\sqrt {2}}}}}}{2}}\cdots } ![{\\frac {2}{\\pi }}={\\frac {\\sqrt {2}}{2}}\\cdot {\\frac {\\sqrt {2+{\\sqrt {2}}}}{2}}\\cdot {\\frac {\\sqrt {2+{\\sqrt {2+{\\sqrt {2}}}}}}{2}}\\cdots ](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/471259d8063f909988b7457a3e2d9c62f73efb01)

The [second infinite sequence found in Europe](/wiki/Wallis_product "Wallis
product"), by [John Wallis](/wiki/John_Wallis "John Wallis") in 1655, was also
an infinite product:[71]

     π 2 = 2 1 ⋅ 2 3 ⋅ 4 3 ⋅ 4 5 ⋅ 6 5 ⋅ 6 7 ⋅ 8 7 ⋅ 8 9 ⋯ {\displaystyle {\frac {\pi }{2}}={\frac {2}{1}}\cdot {\frac {2}{3}}\cdot {\frac {4}{3}}\cdot {\frac {4}{5}}\cdot {\frac {6}{5}}\cdot {\frac {6}{7}}\cdot {\frac {8}{7}}\cdot {\frac {8}{9}}\cdots } ![{\\displaystyle {\\frac {\\pi }{2}}={\\frac {2}{1}}\\cdot {\\frac {2}{3}}\\cdot {\\frac {4}{3}}\\cdot {\\frac {4}{5}}\\cdot {\\frac {6}{5}}\\cdot {\\frac {6}{7}}\\cdot {\\frac {8}{7}}\\cdot {\\frac {8}{9}}\\cdots }](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/794f0375774b4a22f3e96609af6dc97961d8244f)

The discovery of [calculus](/wiki/Calculus "Calculus"), by English scientist
[Isaac Newton](/wiki/Isaac_Newton "Isaac Newton") and German mathematician
[Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz](/wiki/Gottfried_Wilhelm_Leibniz "Gottfried Wilhelm
Leibniz") in the 1660s, led to the development of many infinite series for
approximating π. Newton himself used an arcsin series to compute a 15 digit
approximation of π in 1665 or 1666, later writing "I am ashamed to tell you to
how many figures I carried these computations, having no other business at the
time."[70]

In Europe, Madhava's formula was rediscovered by Scottish mathematician [James
Gregory](/wiki/James_Gregory_\(mathematician\) "James Gregory
\(mathematician\)") in 1671, and by Leibniz in 1674:[74][75]

     arctan ⁡ z = z − z 3 3 + z 5 5 − z 7 7 + ⋯ {\displaystyle \arctan z=z-{\frac {z^{3}}{3}}+{\frac {z^{5}}{5}}-{\frac {z^{7}}{7}}+\cdots } ![\\arctan z=z-{\\frac {z^{3}}{3}}+{\\frac {z^{5}}{5}}-{\\frac {z^{7}}{7}}+\\cdots ](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ef0e80b93f9981701b98f8e121e27c4c50955a3d)

This formula, the Gregory–Leibniz series, equals π/4 when evaluated with _z_ =
1.[75] In 1699, English mathematician [Abraham Sharp](/wiki/Abraham_Sharp
"Abraham Sharp") used the Gregory–Leibniz series for  z = 1 3 {\displaystyle
z={\frac {1}{\sqrt {3}}}} ![{\\displaystyle z={\\frac {1}{\\sqrt
{3}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/745ab451b4d26699936afa5aa364165edeb6dc0f)
to compute π to 71 digits, breaking the previous record of 39 digits, which
was set with a polygonal algorithm.[76] The Gregory–Leibniz for  z = 1
{\displaystyle z=1}
![z=1](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/078535cde78d90bfa1d9fbb2446204593a921d57)
series is simple, but [converges](/wiki/Convergent_series "Convergent series")
very slowly (that is, approaches the answer gradually), so it is not used in
modern π calculations.[77]

In 1706 [John Machin](/wiki/John_Machin "John Machin") used the
Gregory–Leibniz series to produce an algorithm that converged much faster:[78]

     π 4 = 4 arctan ⁡ 1 5 − arctan ⁡ 1 239 {\displaystyle {\frac {\pi }{4}}=4\,\arctan {\frac {1}{5}}-\arctan {\frac {1}{239}}} ![{\\frac {\\pi }{4}}=4\\,\\arctan {\\frac {1}{5}}-\\arctan {\\frac {1}{239}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/0b593efcda1e006c379f96f746c2eb0573753ba2)

Machin reached 100 digits of π with this formula.[79] Other mathematicians
created variants, now known as [Machin-like formulae](/wiki/Machin-
like_formula "Machin-like formula"), that were used to set several successive
records for calculating digits of π.[79] Machin-like formulae remained the
best-known method for calculating π well into the age of computers, and were
used to set records for 250 years, culminating in a 620-digit approximation in
1946 by Daniel Ferguson – the best approximation achieved without the aid of a
calculating device.[80]

A record was set by the calculating prodigy [Zacharias
Dase](/wiki/Zacharias_Dase "Zacharias Dase"), who in 1844 employed a Machin-
like formula to calculate 200 decimals of π in his head at the behest of
German mathematician [Carl Friedrich Gauss](/wiki/Carl_Friedrich_Gauss "Carl
Friedrich Gauss").[81] British mathematician [William
Shanks](/wiki/William_Shanks "William Shanks") famously took 15 years to
calculate π to 707 digits, but made a mistake in the 528th digit, rendering
all subsequent digits incorrect.[81]

#### Rate of convergence

Some infinite series for π [converge](/wiki/Convergent_series "Convergent
series") faster than others. Given the choice of two infinite series for π,
mathematicians will generally use the one that converges more rapidly because
faster convergence reduces the amount of computation needed to calculate π to
any given accuracy.[82] A simple infinite series for π is the [Gregory–Leibniz
series](/wiki/Leibniz_formula_for_%CF%80 "Leibniz formula for π"):[83]

     π = 4 1 − 4 3 + 4 5 − 4 7 + 4 9 − 4 11 + 4 13 − ⋯ {\displaystyle \pi ={\frac {4}{1}}-{\frac {4}{3}}+{\frac {4}{5}}-{\frac {4}{7}}+{\frac {4}{9}}-{\frac {4}{11}}+{\frac {4}{13}}-\cdots } ![\\pi ={\\frac {4}{1}}-{\\frac {4}{3}}+{\\frac {4}{5}}-{\\frac {4}{7}}+{\\frac {4}{9}}-{\\frac {4}{11}}+{\\frac {4}{13}}-\\cdots ](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/e9e3959cd2d0ec735e7a6a1917df784842b76706)

As individual terms of this infinite series are added to the sum, the total
gradually gets closer to π, and – with a sufficient number of terms – can get
as close to π as desired. It converges quite slowly, though – after 500,000
terms, it produces only five correct decimal digits of π.[84]

An infinite series for π (published by Nilakantha in the 15th century) that
converges more rapidly than the Gregory–Leibniz series is:[85]

     π = 3 + 4 2 × 3 × 4 − 4 4 × 5 × 6 + 4 6 × 7 × 8 − 4 8 × 9 × 10 + ⋯ {\displaystyle \pi =3+{\frac {4}{2\times 3\times 4}}-{\frac {4}{4\times 5\times 6}}+{\frac {4}{6\times 7\times 8}}-{\frac {4}{8\times 9\times 10}}+\cdots } ![\\pi =3+{\\frac {4}{2\\times 3\\times 4}}-{\\frac {4}{4\\times 5\\times 6}}+{\\frac {4}{6\\times 7\\times 8}}-{\\frac {4}{8\\times 9\\times 10}}+\\cdots ](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/fdafa8bd24ce2b6fd518a3cf253ad1ef409388a6)

The following table compares the convergence rates of these two series:

Infinite series for π | After 1st term | After 2nd term | After 3rd term | After 4th term | After 5th term | Converges to:  
---|---|---|---|---|---|---  
π = 4 1 − 4 3 + 4 5 − 4 7 + 4 9 − 4 11 + 4 13 ⋯ . {\displaystyle \pi ={\frac {4}{1}}-{\frac {4}{3}}+{\frac {4}{5}}-{\frac {4}{7}}+{\frac {4}{9}}-{\frac {4}{11}}+{\frac {4}{13}}\cdots .} ![\\pi ={\\frac {4}{1}}-{\\frac {4}{3}}+{\\frac {4}{5}}-{\\frac {4}{7}}+{\\frac {4}{9}}-{\\frac {4}{11}}+{\\frac {4}{13}}\\cdots .](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/27cf7d8f4ec3c4be5a8c04637179206b991deb8a) | 4.0000 | 2.6666... | 3.4666... | 2.8952... | 3.3396... | π = 3.1415...  
π = 3 + 4 2 × 3 × 4 − 4 4 × 5 × 6 + 4 6 × 7 × 8 ⋯ . {\displaystyle \pi ={3}+{\frac {4}{2\times 3\times 4}}-{\frac {4}{4\times 5\times 6}}+{\frac {4}{6\times 7\times 8}}\cdots .} ![\\pi ={3}+{\\frac {4}{2\\times 3\\times 4}}-{\\frac {4}{4\\times 5\\times 6}}+{\\frac {4}{6\\times 7\\times 8}}\\cdots .](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/106df4ea6a791a8d224faa4959bc7b43705aedd5) | 3.0000 | 3.1666... | 3.1333... | 3.1452... | 3.1396...  
  
After five terms, the sum of the Gregory–Leibniz series is within 0.2 of the
correct value of π, whereas the sum of Nilakantha's series is within 0.002 of
the correct value of π. Nilakantha's series converges faster and is more
useful for computing digits of π. Series that converge even faster include
[Machin's series](/wiki/Machin-like_formula "Machin-like formula") and
[Chudnovsky's series](/wiki/Chudnovsky_algorithm "Chudnovsky algorithm"), the
latter producing 14 correct decimal digits per term.[82]

### Irrationality and transcendence

See also: [Proof that π is irrational](/wiki/Proof_that_%CF%80_is_irrational
"Proof that π is irrational") and [Proof that π is
transcendental](/wiki/Proof_that_%CF%80_is_transcendental "Proof that π is
transcendental")

Not all mathematical advances relating to π were aimed at increasing the
accuracy of approximations. When Euler solved the [Basel
problem](/wiki/Basel_problem "Basel problem") in 1735, finding the exact value
of the sum of the reciprocal squares, he established a connection between π
and the [prime numbers](/wiki/Prime_number "Prime number") that later
contributed to the development and study of the [Riemann zeta
function](/wiki/Riemann_zeta_function "Riemann zeta function"):[86]

     π 2 6 = 1 1 2 + 1 2 2 + 1 3 2 + 1 4 2 + ⋯ {\displaystyle {\frac {\pi ^{2}}{6}}={\frac {1}{1^{2}}}+{\frac {1}{2^{2}}}+{\frac {1}{3^{2}}}+{\frac {1}{4^{2}}}+\cdots } ![{\\frac {\\pi ^{2}}{6}}={\\frac {1}{1^{2}}}+{\\frac {1}{2^{2}}}+{\\frac {1}{3^{2}}}+{\\frac {1}{4^{2}}}+\\cdots ](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/edf829fbf86ae73080bce0a95c497001b8d15fb1)

Swiss scientist [Johann Heinrich Lambert](/wiki/Johann_Heinrich_Lambert
"Johann Heinrich Lambert") in 1761 proved that π is
[irrational](/wiki/Irrational_number "Irrational number"), meaning it is not
equal to the quotient of any two whole numbers.[19] [Lambert's
proof](/wiki/Proof_that_%CF%80_is_irrational "Proof that π is irrational")
exploited a continued-fraction representation of the tangent function.[87]
French mathematician [Adrien-Marie Legendre](/wiki/Adrien-Marie_Legendre
"Adrien-Marie Legendre") proved in 1794 that π2 is also irrational. In 1882,
German mathematician [Ferdinand von Lindemann](/wiki/Ferdinand_von_Lindemann
"Ferdinand von Lindemann") proved that π is
[transcendental](/wiki/Transcendental_number "Transcendental number"),
confirming a conjecture made by both [Legendre](/wiki/Adrien-Marie_Legendre
"Adrien-Marie Legendre") and Euler.[88][89] Hardy and Wright states that "the
proofs were afterwards modified and simplified by Hilbert, Hurwitz, and other
writers".[90]

### Adoption of the symbol π

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Leonhard_Euler.jpg/170px-
Leonhard_Euler.jpg)](/wiki/File:Leonhard_Euler.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Leonhard_Euler.jpg "Enlarge")

[Leonhard Euler](/wiki/Leonhard_Euler "Leonhard Euler") popularized the use of
the Greek letter π in works he published in 1736 and 1748.

In the earliest usages, the [Greek letter π](/wiki/Pi_\(letter\) "Pi
\(letter\)") was an abbreviation of the Greek word for
[periphery](/wiki/Circumference "Circumference") (περιφέρεια),[91] and was
combined in ratios with [δ](/wiki/Delta_\(letter\) "Delta \(letter\)") (for
[diameter](/wiki/Diameter "Diameter")) or [ρ](/wiki/Rho "Rho") (for
[radius](/wiki/Radius "Radius")) to form circle constants.[92][93][94] (Before
then, mathematicians sometimes used letters such as _c_ or _p_ instead.[95])
The first recorded use is [Oughtred's](/wiki/William_Oughtred "William
Oughtred") "δ.π", to express the ratio of periphery and diameter in the 1647
and later editions of _Clavis Mathematicae_.[96][95]
[Barrow](/wiki/Isaac_Barrow "Isaac Barrow") likewise used " π δ {\textstyle
{\frac {\pi }{\delta }}} ![{\\textstyle {\\frac {\\pi }{\\delta
}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a466800781ba6342e20a4855043f667cf417c868)"
to represent the constant 3.14…,[97] while
[Gregory](/wiki/David_Gregory_\(mathematician\) "David Gregory
\(mathematician\)") instead used " π ρ {\textstyle {\frac {\pi }{\rho }}}
![{\\textstyle {\\frac {\\pi }{\\rho
}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/f62f00c9d88b9d6b7d4401227a9289982b4820a6)"
to represent 6.28….[98][93]

The earliest known use of the Greek letter π alone to represent the ratio of a
circle's circumference to its diameter was by Welsh mathematician [William
Jones](/wiki/William_Jones_\(mathematician\) "William Jones
\(mathematician\)") in his 1706 work _Synopsis Palmariorum Matheseos; or, a
New Introduction to the Mathematics_.[99][100] The Greek letter first appears
there in the phrase "1/2 Periphery (π)" in the discussion of a circle with
radius one.[101] However, he writes that his equations for π are from the
"ready pen of the truly ingenious Mr. [John Machin](/wiki/John_Machin "John
Machin")", leading to speculation that Machin may have employed the Greek
letter before Jones.[95] Jones' notation was not immediately adopted by other
mathematicians, with the fraction notation still being used as late as
1767.[92][102]

[Euler](/wiki/Euler "Euler") started using the single-letter form beginning
with his 1727 _Essay Explaining The Properties Of Air_ , though he used π =
6.28…, the ratio of radius to periphery, in this and some later
writing.[103][104] Euler first used π=3.14… in his 1736 work
_[Mechanica](/wiki/Mechanica "Mechanica")_ ,[105] and continued in his widely-
read 1748 work _[Introductio in analysin
infinitorum](/wiki/Introductio_in_analysin_infinitorum "Introductio in
analysin infinitorum")_ (he wrote: "for the sake of brevity we will write this
number as π; thus π is equal to half the circumference of a circle of radius
1").[106] Because Euler corresponded heavily with other mathematicians in
Europe, the use of the Greek letter spread rapidly, and the practice was
universally adopted thereafter in the [Western world](/wiki/Western_world
"Western world").[95]

## Modern quest for more digits

### Computer era and iterative algorithms

[![Formal photo of a balding man wearing a
suit](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/JohnvonNeumann-
LosAlamos.gif/170px-JohnvonNeumann-LosAlamos.gif)](/wiki/File:JohnvonNeumann-
LosAlamos.gif)

[](/wiki/File:JohnvonNeumann-LosAlamos.gif "Enlarge")

[John von Neumann](/wiki/John_von_Neumann "John von Neumann") was part of the
team that first used a digital computer, [ENIAC](/wiki/ENIAC "ENIAC"), to
compute π.

The [Gauss–Legendre iterative
algorithm](/wiki/Gauss%E2%80%93Legendre_algorithm "Gauss–Legendre algorithm"):  
Initialize

     a 0 = 1 b 0 = 1 2 t 0 = 1 4 p 0 = 1 {\displaystyle \scriptstyle a_{0}=1\quad b_{0}={\frac {1}{\sqrt {2}}}\quad t_{0}={\frac {1}{4}}\quad p_{0}=1} ![\\scriptstyle a_{0}=1\\quad b_{0}={\\frac {1}{\\sqrt {2}}}\\quad t_{0}={\\frac {1}{4}}\\quad p_{0}=1](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/5a560b072a78b0ed5ad747189345bca97d2ca970)

Iterate

     a n + 1 = a n + b n 2 b n + 1 = a n b n {\displaystyle \scriptstyle a_{n+1}={\frac {a_{n}+b_{n}}{2}}\quad \quad b_{n+1}={\sqrt {a_{n}b_{n}}}} ![\\scriptstyle a_{n+1}={\\frac {a_{n}+b_{n}}{2}}\\quad \\quad b_{n+1}={\\sqrt {a_{n}b_{n}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/62eccee35292e969c2a1f4110b9d6413eaf577bc)
     t n + 1 = t n − p n ( a n − a n + 1 ) 2 p n + 1 = 2 p n {\displaystyle \scriptstyle t_{n+1}=t_{n}-p_{n}(a_{n}-a_{n+1})^{2}\quad \quad p_{n+1}=2p_{n}} ![\\scriptstyle t_{n+1}=t_{n}-p_{n}\(a_{n}-a_{n+1}\)^{2}\\quad \\quad p_{n+1}=2p_{n}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/abceba402767c95fabacf49a73ac4c666e61d4a3)

Then an estimate for π is given by

     π ≈ ( a n + b n ) 2 4 t n {\displaystyle \scriptstyle \pi \approx {\frac {(a_{n}+b_{n})^{2}}{4t_{n}}}} ![\\scriptstyle \\pi \\approx {\\frac {\(a_{n}+b_{n}\)^{2}}{4t_{n}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/9fbdf5841be34f375e64b3165ea92230afcdd604)

The development of computers in the mid-20th century again revolutionized the
hunt for digits of π. American mathematicians [John Wrench](/wiki/John_Wrench
"John Wrench") and Levi Smith reached 1,120 digits in 1949 using a desk
calculator.[107] Using an [inverse tangent](/wiki/Inverse_tangent "Inverse
tangent") (arctan) infinite series, a team led by George Reitwiesner and [John
von Neumann](/wiki/John_von_Neumann "John von Neumann") that same year
achieved 2,037 digits with a calculation that took 70 hours of computer time
on the [ENIAC](/wiki/ENIAC "ENIAC") computer.[108] The record, always relying
on an arctan series, was broken repeatedly (7,480 digits in 1957; 10,000
digits in 1958; 100,000 digits in 1961) until 1 million digits were reached in
1973.[109]

Two additional developments around 1980 once again accelerated the ability to
compute π. First, the discovery of new [iterative
algorithms](/wiki/Iterative_algorithm "Iterative algorithm") for computing π,
which were much faster than the infinite series; and second, the invention of
[fast multiplication
algorithms](/wiki/Multiplication_algorithm#Fast_multiplication_algorithms_for_large_inputs
"Multiplication algorithm") that could multiply large numbers very
rapidly.[110] Such algorithms are particularly important in modern π
computations, because most of the computer's time is devoted to
multiplication.[111] They include the [Karatsuba
algorithm](/wiki/Karatsuba_algorithm "Karatsuba algorithm"), [Toom–Cook
multiplication](/wiki/Toom%E2%80%93Cook_multiplication "Toom–Cook
multiplication"), and [Fourier transform-based
methods](/wiki/FFT_multiplication#Fourier_transform_methods "FFT
multiplication").[112]

The iterative algorithms were independently published in 1975–1976 by American
physicist [Eugene Salamin](/wiki/Eugene_Salamin_\(mathematician\) "Eugene
Salamin \(mathematician\)") and Australian scientist [Richard
Brent](/wiki/Richard_Brent_\(scientist\) "Richard Brent \(scientist\)").[113]
These avoid reliance on infinite series. An iterative algorithm repeats a
specific calculation, each iteration using the outputs from prior steps as its
inputs, and produces a result in each step that converges to the desired
value. The approach was actually invented over 160 years earlier by [Carl
Friedrich Gauss](/wiki/Carl_Friedrich_Gauss "Carl Friedrich Gauss"), in what
is now termed the [arithmetic–geometric mean method](/wiki/AGM_method "AGM
method") (AGM method) or [Gauss–Legendre
algorithm](/wiki/Gauss%E2%80%93Legendre_algorithm "Gauss–Legendre
algorithm").[113] As modified by Salamin and Brent, it is also referred to as
the Brent–Salamin algorithm.

The iterative algorithms were widely used after 1980 because they are faster
than infinite series algorithms: whereas infinite series typically increase
the number of correct digits additively in successive terms, iterative
algorithms generally _multiply_ the number of correct digits at each step. For
example, the Brent-Salamin algorithm doubles the number of digits in each
iteration. In 1984, the Canadian brothers [John](/wiki/Jonathan_Borwein
"Jonathan Borwein") and [Peter Borwein](/wiki/Peter_Borwein "Peter Borwein")
produced an iterative algorithm that quadruples the number of digits in each
step; and in 1987, one that increases the number of digits five times in each
step.[114] Iterative methods were used by Japanese mathematician [Yasumasa
Kanada](/wiki/Yasumasa_Kanada "Yasumasa Kanada") to set several records for
computing π between 1995 and 2002.[115] This rapid convergence comes at a
price: the iterative algorithms require significantly more memory than
infinite series.[115]

### Motives for computing π

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Record_pi_approximations.svg/400px-
Record_pi_approximations.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Record_pi_approximations.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Record_pi_approximations.svg "Enlarge")

As mathematicians discovered new algorithms, and computers became available,
the number of known decimal digits of π increased dramatically. Note that the
vertical scale is [logarithmic](/wiki/Logarithm "Logarithm").

For most numerical calculations involving π, a handful of digits provide
sufficient precision. According to Jörg Arndt and Christoph Haenel, thirty-
nine digits are sufficient to perform most [cosmological](/wiki/Cosmological
"Cosmological") calculations, because that is the accuracy necessary to
calculate the circumference of the [observable
universe](/wiki/Observable_universe "Observable universe") with a precision of
one atom.[116] Despite this, people have worked strenuously to compute π to
thousands and millions of digits.[117] This effort may be partly ascribed to
the human compulsion to break records, and such achievements with π often make
headlines around the world.[118][119] They also have practical benefits, such
as testing [supercomputers](/wiki/Supercomputer "Supercomputer"), testing
numerical analysis algorithms (including [high-precision multiplication
algorithms](/wiki/Multiplication_algorithm#Fast_multiplication_algorithms_for_large_inputs
"Multiplication algorithm")); and within pure mathematics itself, providing
data for evaluating the randomness of the digits of π.[120]

### Rapidly convergent series

[![Photo portrait of a
man](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Srinivasa_Ramanujan_-
_OPC_-_1.jpg/170px-Srinivasa_Ramanujan_-
_OPC_-_1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Srinivasa_Ramanujan_-_OPC_-_1.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Srinivasa_Ramanujan_-_OPC_-_1.jpg "Enlarge")

[Srinivasa Ramanujan](/wiki/Srinivasa_Ramanujan "Srinivasa Ramanujan"),
working in isolation in India, produced many innovative series for computing
π.

Modern π calculators do not use iterative algorithms exclusively. New infinite
series were discovered in the 1980s and 1990s that are as fast as iterative
algorithms, yet are simpler and less memory intensive.[115] The fast iterative
algorithms were anticipated in 1914, when the Indian mathematician [Srinivasa
Ramanujan](/wiki/Srinivasa_Ramanujan "Srinivasa Ramanujan") published dozens
of innovative new formulae for π, remarkable for their elegance, mathematical
depth, and rapid convergence.[121] One of his formulae, based on [modular
equations](/wiki/Modular_equation "Modular equation"), is

     1 π = 2 2 9801 ∑ k = 0 ∞ ( 4 k ) ! ( 1103 + 26390 k ) k ! 4 ( 396 4 k ) . {\displaystyle {\frac {1}{\pi }}={\frac {2{\sqrt {2}}}{9801}}\sum _{k=0}^{\infty }{\frac {(4k)!(1103+26390k)}{k!^{4}(396^{4k})}}.} ![{\\frac {1}{\\pi }}={\\frac {2{\\sqrt {2}}}{9801}}\\sum _{k=0}^{\\infty }{\\frac {\(4k\)!\(1103+26390k\)}{k!^{4}\(396^{4k}\)}}.](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/911bfd1b5a6584fdcd7f82c6a92cc67c088e5659)

This series converges much more rapidly than most arctan series, including
Machin's formula.[122] [Bill Gosper](/wiki/Bill_Gosper "Bill Gosper") was the
first to use it for advances in the calculation of π, setting a record of 17
million digits in 1985.[123] Ramanujan's formulae anticipated the modern
algorithms developed by the Borwein brothers and the [Chudnovsky
brothers](/wiki/Chudnovsky_brothers "Chudnovsky brothers").[124] The
[Chudnovsky formula](/wiki/Chudnovsky_algorithm "Chudnovsky algorithm")
developed in 1987 is

     1 π = 12 640320 3 / 2 ∑ k = 0 ∞ ( 6 k ) ! ( 13591409 + 545140134 k ) ( 3 k ) ! ( k ! ) 3 ( − 640320 ) 3 k . {\displaystyle {\frac {1}{\pi }}={\frac {12}{640320^{3/2}}}\sum _{k=0}^{\infty }{\frac {(6k)!(13591409+545140134k)}{(3k)!(k!)^{3}(-640320)^{3k}}}.} ![{\\frac {1}{\\pi }}={\\frac {12}{640320^{3/2}}}\\sum _{k=0}^{\\infty }{\\frac {\(6k\)!\(13591409+545140134k\)}{\(3k\)!\(k!\)^{3}\(-640320\)^{3k}}}.](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/f28064333a8ea76f941a065cd4680accb1519887)

It produces about 14 digits of π per term,[125] and has been used for several
record-setting π calculations, including the first to surpass 1 billion (109)
digits in 1989 by the Chudnovsky brothers, 2.7 trillion (2.7×1012) digits by
[Fabrice Bellard](/wiki/Fabrice_Bellard "Fabrice Bellard") in 2009, and 10
trillion (1013) digits in 2011 by Alexander Yee and Shigeru Kondo.[126][127]
For similar formulas, see also the [Ramanujan–Sato
series](/wiki/Ramanujan%E2%80%93Sato_series "Ramanujan–Sato series").

In 2006, Canadian mathematician [Simon Plouffe](/wiki/Simon_Plouffe "Simon
Plouffe") used the PSLQ [integer relation
algorithm](/wiki/Integer_relation_algorithm "Integer relation algorithm")[128]
to generate several new formulas for π, conforming to the following template:

     π k = ∑ n = 1 ∞ 1 n k ( a q n − 1 + b q 2 n − 1 + c q 4 n − 1 ) , {\displaystyle \pi ^{k}=\sum _{n=1}^{\infty }{\frac {1}{n^{k}}}\left({\frac {a}{q^{n}-1}}+{\frac {b}{q^{2n}-1}}+{\frac {c}{q^{4n}-1}}\right),} ![\\pi ^{k}=\\sum _{n=1}^{\\infty }{\\frac {1}{n^{k}}}\\left\({\\frac {a}{q^{n}-1}}+{\\frac {b}{q^{2n}-1}}+{\\frac {c}{q^{4n}-1}}\\right\),](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/948b735a39a1bbf9a39ba0b6bd7dc63bddcd4351)

where _q_ is [eπ](/wiki/Gelfond%27s_constant "Gelfond's constant") (Gelfond's
constant), _k_ is an [odd number](/wiki/Odd_number "Odd number"), and _a_ ,
_b_ , _c_ are certain rational numbers that Plouffe computed.[129]

### Monte Carlo methods

[![Needles of length ℓ scattered on stripes with width
t](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Buffon_needle.svg/166px-
Buffon_needle.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Buffon_needle.svg)

[Buffon's needle](/wiki/Buffon%27s_needle "Buffon's needle"). Needles _a_ and
_b_ are dropped randomly.

[![Thousands of dots randomly covering a square and a circle inscribed in the
square.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Pi_30K.gif/100px-
Pi_30K.gif)](/wiki/File:Pi_30K.gif)

Random dots are placed on the quadrant of a square with a circle inscribed in
it.

[Monte Carlo methods](/wiki/Monte_Carlo_method "Monte Carlo method"), based on
random trials, can be used to approximate π.

[Monte Carlo methods](/wiki/Monte_Carlo_methods "Monte Carlo methods"), which
evaluate the results of multiple random trials, can be used to create
approximations of π.[130] [Buffon's needle](/wiki/Buffon%27s_needle "Buffon's
needle") is one such technique: If a needle of length _ℓ_ is dropped _n_ times
on a surface on which parallel lines are drawn _t_ units apart, and if _x_ of
those times it comes to rest crossing a line (_x_ > 0), then one may
approximate π based on the counts:[131]

     π ≈ 2 n ℓ x t {\displaystyle \pi \approx {\frac {2n\ell }{xt}}} ![\\pi \\approx {\\frac {2n\\ell }{xt}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/b8061e9c23c43baf32ef7052600d2cfe90c6a178)

Another Monte Carlo method for computing π is to draw a circle inscribed in a
square, and randomly place dots in the square. The ratio of dots inside the
circle to the total number of dots will approximately equal π/4.[132]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/e/e4/Five_random_walks.png/220px-
Five_random_walks.png)](/wiki/File:Five_random_walks.png)

[](/wiki/File:Five_random_walks.png "Enlarge")

Five random walks with 200 steps. The sample mean of |_W_ 200| is μ = 56/5,
and so 2(200)μ−2 ≈ 3.19 is within 0.05 of π

Another way to calculate π using probability is to start with a [random
walk](/wiki/Random_walk "Random walk"), generated by a sequence of (fair) coin
tosses: independent [random variables](/wiki/Random_variable "Random
variable") _X k_ such that _X k_ ∈ {−1,1} with equal probabilities. The
associated random walk is

     W n = ∑ k = 1 n X k {\displaystyle W_{n}=\sum _{k=1}^{n}X_{k}} ![{\\displaystyle W_{n}=\\sum _{k=1}^{n}X_{k}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ff50676493705f91fc45cb5ab160083bbf7aa669)

so that, for each _n_ , _W n_ is drawn from a standard [binomial
distribution](/wiki/Binomial_distribution "Binomial distribution"). As _n_
varies _W n_ defines a (discrete) [stochastic
process](/wiki/Stochastic_process "Stochastic process"). Then π can be
calculated by[133]

     π = lim n → ∞ 2 n E [ | W n | ] 2 . {\displaystyle \pi =\lim _{n\to \infty }{\frac {2n}{E[|W_{n}|]^{2}}}.} ![{\\displaystyle \\pi =\\lim _{n\\to \\infty }{\\frac {2n}{E\[|W_{n}|\]^{2}}}.}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a691be63815c6b7d9fe15070ae98039d9c1d0384)

This Monte Carlo method is independent of any relation to circles, and is a
consequence of the [central limit theorem](/wiki/Central_limit_theorem
"Central limit theorem"), discussed above.

These Monte Carlo methods for approximating π are very slow compared to other
methods, and do not provide any information on the exact number of digits that
are obtained. Thus they are never used to approximate π when speed or accuracy
is desired.[134]

### Spigot algorithms

Two algorithms were discovered in 1995 that opened up new avenues of research
into π. They are called [spigot algorithms](/wiki/Spigot_algorithm "Spigot
algorithm") because, like water dripping from a [spigot](/wiki/Tap_\(valve\)
"Tap \(valve\)"), they produce single digits of π that are not reused after
they are calculated.[135][136] This is in contrast to infinite series or
iterative algorithms, which retain and use all intermediate digits until the
final result is produced.[135]

American mathematicians [Stan Wagon](/wiki/Stan_Wagon "Stan Wagon") and
Stanley Rabinowitz produced a simple spigot algorithm in 1995.[136][137][138]
Its speed is comparable to arctan algorithms, but not as fast as iterative
algorithms.[137]

Another spigot algorithm, the
[BBP](/wiki/Bailey%E2%80%93Borwein%E2%80%93Plouffe_formula
"Bailey–Borwein–Plouffe formula") [digit extraction
algorithm](/wiki/Digit_extraction_algorithm "Digit extraction algorithm"), was
discovered in 1995 by Simon Plouffe:[139][140]

     π = ∑ k = 0 ∞ 1 16 k ( 4 8 k + 1 − 2 8 k + 4 − 1 8 k + 5 − 1 8 k + 6 ) {\displaystyle \pi =\sum _{k=0}^{\infty }{\frac {1}{16^{k}}}\left({\frac {4}{8k+1}}-{\frac {2}{8k+4}}-{\frac {1}{8k+5}}-{\frac {1}{8k+6}}\right)} ![\\pi =\\sum _{k=0}^{\\infty }{\\frac {1}{16^{k}}}\\left\({\\frac {4}{8k+1}}-{\\frac {2}{8k+4}}-{\\frac {1}{8k+5}}-{\\frac {1}{8k+6}}\\right\)](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/5be33d7e24e7ab4d284dd957955227fb6faee2d3)

This formula, unlike others before it, can produce any individual
[hexadecimal](/wiki/Hexadecimal "Hexadecimal") digit of π without calculating
all the preceding digits.[139] Individual binary digits may be extracted from
individual hexadecimal digits, and [octal](/wiki/Octal "Octal") digits can be
extracted from one or two hexadecimal digits. Variations of the algorithm have
been discovered, but no digit extraction algorithm has yet been found that
rapidly produces decimal digits.[141] An important application of digit
extraction algorithms is to validate new claims of record π computations:
After a new record is claimed, the decimal result is converted to hexadecimal,
and then a digit extraction algorithm is used to calculate several random
hexadecimal digits near the end; if they match, this provides a measure of
confidence that the entire computation is correct.[127]

Between 1998 and 2000, the [distributed computing](/wiki/Distributed_computing
"Distributed computing") project [PiHex](/wiki/PiHex "PiHex") used [Bellard's
formula](/wiki/Bellard%27s_formula "Bellard's formula") (a modification of the
BBP algorithm) to compute the quadrillionth (1015th) bit of π, which turned
out to be 0.[142] In September 2010, a [Yahoo!](/wiki/Yahoo! "Yahoo!")
employee used the company's [Hadoop](/wiki/Apache_Hadoop "Apache Hadoop")
application on one thousand computers over a 23-day period to compute 256
[bits](/wiki/Bit "Bit") of π at the two-quadrillionth (2×1015th) bit, which
also happens to be zero.[143]

## Role and characterizations in mathematics

Because π is closely related to the circle, it is found in [many
formulae](/wiki/List_of_formulae_involving_%CF%80 "List of formulae involving
π") from the fields of geometry and trigonometry, particularly those
concerning circles, spheres, or ellipses. Other branches of science, such as
statistics, physics, [Fourier analysis](/wiki/Fourier_analysis "Fourier
analysis"), and number theory, also include π in some of their important
formulae.

### Geometry and trigonometry

[![A diagram of a circle with a square coving the circle's upper right
quadrant.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Circle_Area.svg/220px-
Circle_Area.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Circle_Area.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Circle_Area.svg "Enlarge")

The area of the circle equals π times the shaded area.

π appears in formulae for areas and volumes of geometrical shapes based on
circles, such as [ellipses](/wiki/Ellipse "Ellipse"), [spheres](/wiki/Sphere
"Sphere"), [cones](/wiki/Cone_\(geometry\) "Cone \(geometry\)"), and
[tori](/wiki/Torus "Torus"). Below are some of the more common formulae that
involve π.[144]

  * The circumference of a circle with radius _r_ is 2π _r_.
  * The [area of a circle](/wiki/Area_of_a_disk "Area of a disk") with radius _r_ is π _r_ 2.
  * The volume of a sphere with radius _r_ is 4/3π _r_ 3.
  * The surface area of a sphere with radius _r_ is 4π _r_ 2.

The formulae above are special cases of the volume of the [_n_ -dimensional
ball](/wiki/N-ball "N-ball") and the surface area of its boundary, the [(_n_
−1)-dimensional sphere](/wiki/N-sphere "N-sphere"), given below.

[Definite integrals](/wiki/Integral "Integral") that describe circumference,
area, or volume of shapes generated by circles typically have values that
involve π. For example, an integral that specifies half the area of a circle
of radius one is given by:[145]

     ∫ − 1 1 1 − x 2 d x = π 2 . {\displaystyle \int _{-1}^{1}{\sqrt {1-x^{2}}}\,dx={\frac {\pi }{2}}.} ![\\int _{-1}^{1}{\\sqrt {1-x^{2}}}\\,dx={\\frac {\\pi }{2}}.](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/1955a15a053adcb91a83af56ea651085c2c18353)

In that integral the function √1 −  _x_ 2 represents the top half of a circle
(the [square root](/wiki/Square_root "Square root") is a consequence of the
[Pythagorean theorem](/wiki/Pythagorean_theorem "Pythagorean theorem")), and
the integral ∫1  
−1 computes the area between that half of a circle and the [_x_
axis](/wiki/X_axis "X axis").

[![Diagram showing graphs of
functions](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Sine_cosine_one_period.svg/340px-
Sine_cosine_one_period.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Sine_cosine_one_period.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Sine_cosine_one_period.svg "Enlarge")

[Sine](/wiki/Sine "Sine") and [cosine](/wiki/Cosine "Cosine") functions repeat
with period 2π.

The [trigonometric functions](/wiki/Trigonometric_function "Trigonometric
function") rely on angles, and mathematicians generally use radians as units
of measurement. π plays an important role in angles measured in
[radians](/wiki/Radian "Radian"), which are defined so that a complete circle
spans an angle of 2π radians.[146] The angle measure of 180° is equal to π
radians, and 1° = π/180 radians.[146]

Common trigonometric functions have periods that are multiples of π; for
example, sine and cosine have period 2π,[147] so for any angle _θ_ and any
integer _k_ ,

     sin ⁡ θ = sin ⁡ ( θ + 2 π k ) and  cos ⁡ θ = cos ⁡ ( θ + 2 π k ) . {\displaystyle \sin \theta =\sin \left(\theta +2\pi k\right){\text{ and }}\cos \theta =\cos \left(\theta +2\pi k\right).} ![{\\displaystyle \\sin \\theta =\\sin \\left\(\\theta +2\\pi k\\right\){\\text{ and }}\\cos \\theta =\\cos \\left\(\\theta +2\\pi k\\right\).}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/f3b3c88ab8201f4f0c6f18dd73cb951ebcd07e2a)[147]

### Eigenvalues

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Harmonic_partials_on_strings.svg/220px-
Harmonic_partials_on_strings.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Harmonic_partials_on_strings.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Harmonic_partials_on_strings.svg "Enlarge")

The [overtones](/wiki/Overtone "Overtone") of a vibrating string are
[eigenfunctions](/wiki/Eigenfunction "Eigenfunction") of the second
derivative, and form a [harmonic progression](/wiki/Harmonic_series_\(music\)
"Harmonic series \(music\)"). The associated eigenvalues form the [arithmetic
progression](/wiki/Arithmetic_progression "Arithmetic progression") of integer
multiples of π.

Many of the appearances of π in the formulas of mathematics and the sciences
have to do with its close relationship with geometry. However, π also appears
in many natural situations having apparently nothing to do with geometry.

In many applications it plays a distinguished role as an
[eigenvalue](/wiki/Eigenvalue "Eigenvalue"). For example, an idealized
[vibrating string](/wiki/Vibrating_string "Vibrating string") can be modelled
as the graph of a function _f_ on the unit interval [0,1], with [fixed
ends](/wiki/Boundary_conditions "Boundary conditions") _f_(0) = _f_(1) = 0.
The modes of vibration of the string are solutions of the [differential
equation](/wiki/Differential_equation "Differential equation") _f_ "(_x_) + λ
_f_(_x_) = 0. Here λ is an associated eigenvalue, which is constrained by
[Sturm–Liouville theory](/wiki/Sturm%E2%80%93Liouville_theory "Sturm–Liouville
theory") to take on only certain specific values. It must be positive, since
the second derivative is [negative definite](/wiki/Negative_definite "Negative
definite"), so it is convenient to write λ = ν2 where ν > 0 is called the
[wavenumber](/wiki/Wavenumber "Wavenumber"). Then _f_(_x_) = sin(π _x_)
satisfies the boundary conditions and the differential equation with ν =
π.[148]

The value π is in fact the _least_ such value of the wavenumber, and is
associated with the [fundamental mode](/wiki/Fundamental_mode "Fundamental
mode") of vibration of the string. One way to obtain this is by estimating the
[energy](/wiki/Energy "Energy"). The energy satisfies an inequality,
[Wirtinger's inequality for
functions](/wiki/Wirtinger%27s_inequality_for_functions "Wirtinger's
inequality for functions"),[149] which states that if a function _f_ : [0, 1]
→ ℂ is given such that _f_(0) = _f_(1) = 0 and _f_ and _f_ ' are both [square
integrable](/wiki/Square_integrable "Square integrable"), then the inequality
holds:

     π 2 ∫ 0 1 | f ( x ) | 2 d x ≤ ∫ 0 1 | f ′ ( x ) | 2 d x , {\displaystyle \pi ^{2}\int _{0}^{1}|f(x)|^{2}\,dx\leq \int _{0}^{1}|f'(x)|^{2}\,dx,} ![{\\displaystyle \\pi ^{2}\\int _{0}^{1}|f\(x\)|^{2}\\,dx\\leq \\int _{0}^{1}|f'\(x\)|^{2}\\,dx,}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/9021233d9bdca65d39dc801347f5901f04e55204)

and the case of equality holds precisely when _f_ is a multiple of sin(π _x_).
So π appears as an optimal constant in Wirtinger's inequality, and from this
it follows that it is the smallest such wavenumber, using the [variational
characterization](/wiki/Variational_theorem "Variational theorem") of the
eigenvalue. As a consequence, π is the smallest [singular
value](/wiki/Singular_value "Singular value") of the derivative on the space
of functions on [0,1] vanishing at both endpoints (the [Sobolev
space](/wiki/Sobolev_space "Sobolev space") H 0 1 [ 0 , 1 ] {\displaystyle
H_{0}^{1}[0,1]} ![{\\displaystyle
H_{0}^{1}\[0,1\]}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/7113d194de39d54621e9da47782ad5263b9f1790)).

### Inequalities

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Sir_William_Thompson_illustration_of_Carthage.png/220px-
Sir_William_Thompson_illustration_of_Carthage.png)](/wiki/File:Sir_William_Thompson_illustration_of_Carthage.png)

[](/wiki/File:Sir_William_Thompson_illustration_of_Carthage.png "Enlarge")

The [ancient city of Carthage](/wiki/Ancient_Carthage "Ancient Carthage") was
the solution to an isoperimetric problem, according to a legend recounted by
[Lord Kelvin](/wiki/Lord_Kelvin "Lord Kelvin") (Thompson 1894): those lands
bordering the sea that [Queen Dido](/wiki/Dido "Dido") could enclose on all
other sides within a single given oxhide, cut into strips.

The number π serves appears in similar eigenvalue problems in higher-
dimensional analysis. As mentioned above, it can be characterized via its role
as the best constant in the [isoperimetric
inequality](/wiki/Isoperimetric_inequality "Isoperimetric inequality"): the
area A enclosed by a plane [Jordan curve](/wiki/Jordan_curve "Jordan curve")
of perimeter P satisfies the inequality

     4 π A ≤ P 2 , {\displaystyle 4\pi A\leq P^{2},} ![{\\displaystyle 4\\pi A\\leq P^{2},}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/2da151eb3d06c6538dfa721d85c36e2b052a5114)

and equality is clearly achieved for the circle, since in that case _A_ = π
_r_ 2 and _P_ = 2π _r_.[150]

Ultimately as a consequence of the isoperimetric inequality, π appears in the
optimal constant for the critical [Sobolev
inequality](/wiki/Sobolev_inequality "Sobolev inequality") in _n_ dimensions,
which thus characterizes the role of π in many physical phenomena as well, for
example those of classical [potential theory](/wiki/Potential_theory
"Potential theory").[151][152][153] In two dimensions, the critical Sobolev
inequality is

     2 π ∥ f ∥ 2 ≤ ∥ ∇ f ∥ 1 {\displaystyle 2\pi \|f\|_{2}\leq \|\nabla f\|_{1}} ![{\\displaystyle 2\\pi \\|f\\|_{2}\\leq \\|\\nabla f\\|_{1}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a80eaaf07fddda0c919000c07fda359208e10cf9)

for _f_ a smooth function with compact support in **R** 2,  ∇ f {\displaystyle
\nabla f} ![\\nabla
f](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/b7b4d6de89b52c5a5e6e1583cb63eaee263e307b)
is the [gradient](/wiki/Gradient "Gradient") of _f_ , and  ∥ f ∥ 2
{\displaystyle \|f\|_{2}} ![{\\displaystyle
\\|f\\|_{2}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/7d0c64fd6ef8f74eac7ace4d9b3db3f4d148385d)
and  ∥ ∇ f ∥ 1 {\displaystyle \|\nabla f\|_{1}} ![{\\displaystyle \\|\\nabla
f\\|_{1}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/7de8dc3d0605c979ebae27c6791e3df7b1c19887)
refer respectively to the [L2 and L1-norm](/wiki/Lp_space "Lp space"). The
Sobolev inequality is equivalent to the isoperimetric inequality (in any
dimension), with the same best constants.

Wirtinger's inequality also generalizes to higher-dimensional [Poincaré
inequalities](/wiki/Poincar%C3%A9_inequality "Poincaré inequality") that
provide best constants for the [Dirichlet energy](/wiki/Dirichlet_energy
"Dirichlet energy") of an _n_ -dimensional membrane. Specifically, π is the
greatest constant such that

     π ≤ ( ∫ G | ∇ u | 2 ) 1 / 2 ( ∫ G | u | 2 ) 1 / 2 {\displaystyle \pi \leq {\frac {\left(\int _{G}|\nabla u|^{2}\right)^{1/2}}{\left(\int _{G}|u|^{2}\right)^{1/2}}}} ![{\\displaystyle \\pi \\leq {\\frac {\\left\(\\int _{G}|\\nabla u|^{2}\\right\)^{1/2}}{\\left\(\\int _{G}|u|^{2}\\right\)^{1/2}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/72b72bae66777c4041fd32d69be2a43a740bd885)

for all [convex](/wiki/Convex_set "Convex set") subsets _G_ of **R** _n_ of
diameter 1, and square-integrable functions _u_ on _G_ of mean zero.[154] Just
as Wirtinger's inequality is the [variational](/wiki/Calculus_of_variations
"Calculus of variations") form of the [Dirichlet
eigenvalue](/wiki/Dirichlet_eigenvalue "Dirichlet eigenvalue") problem in one
dimension, the Poincaré inequality is the variational form of the
[Neumann](/wiki/Neumann_problem "Neumann problem") eigenvalue problem, in any
dimension.

### Fourier transform and Heisenberg uncertainty principle

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/00/Animation_of_Heisenberg_geodesic.gif/220px-
Animation_of_Heisenberg_geodesic.gif)](/wiki/File:Animation_of_Heisenberg_geodesic.gif)

[](/wiki/File:Animation_of_Heisenberg_geodesic.gif "Enlarge")

An animation of a [geodesic in the Heisenberg
group](/wiki/Heisenberg_group#As_a_sub-Riemannian_manifold "Heisenberg
group"), showing the close connection between the Heisenberg group,
isoperimetry, and the constant π. The cumulative height of the geodesic is
equal to the area of the shaded portion of the unit circle, while the arc
length (in the [Carnot–Carathéodory
metric](/wiki/Carnot%E2%80%93Carath%C3%A9odory_metric "Carnot–Carathéodory
metric")) is equal to the circumference.

The constant π also appears as a critical spectral parameter in the [Fourier
transform](/wiki/Fourier_transform "Fourier transform"). This is the [integral
transform](/wiki/Integral_transform "Integral transform"), that takes a
complex-valued integrable function _f_ on the real line to the function
defined as:

     f ^ ( ξ ) = ∫ − ∞ ∞ f ( x ) e − 2 π i x ξ d x . {\displaystyle {\hat {f}}(\xi )=\int _{-\infty }^{\infty }f(x)e^{-2\pi ix\xi }\,dx.} ![{\\displaystyle {\\hat {f}}\(\\xi \)=\\int _{-\\infty }^{\\infty }f\(x\)e^{-2\\pi ix\\xi }\\,dx.}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/4a78cc05a0945443f61906a7c66822e38839e84f)

There are several different conventions for the Fourier transform, all of
which involve a factor of π that is placed _somewhere_. The appearance of π is
essential in these formulas, as there is there is no possibility to remove π
altogether from the Fourier transform and its inverse transform. The
definition given above is the most canonical however, because it describes the
unique unitary operator on _L_ 2 that is also an algebra homomorphism of _L_ 1
to _L_ ∞.[155]

The [Heisenberg uncertainty principle](/wiki/Heisenberg_uncertainty_principle
"Heisenberg uncertainty principle") also contains the number π. The
uncertainty principle gives a sharp lower bound on the extent to which it is
possible to localize a function both in space and in frequency: with our
conventions for the Fourier transform,

     ∫ − ∞ ∞ x 2 | f ( x ) | 2 d x ∫ − ∞ ∞ ξ 2 | f ^ ( ξ ) | 2 d ξ ≥ ( 1 4 π ∫ − ∞ ∞ | f ( x ) | 2 d x ) 2 . {\displaystyle \int _{-\infty }^{\infty }x^{2}|f(x)|^{2}\,dx\ \int _{-\infty }^{\infty }\xi ^{2}|{\hat {f}}(\xi )|^{2}\,d\xi \geq \left({\frac {1}{4\pi }}\int _{-\infty }^{\infty }|f(x)|^{2}\,dx\right)^{2}.} ![{\\displaystyle \\int _{-\\infty }^{\\infty }x^{2}|f\(x\)|^{2}\\,dx\\ \\int _{-\\infty }^{\\infty }\\xi ^{2}|{\\hat {f}}\(\\xi \)|^{2}\\,d\\xi \\geq \\left\({\\frac {1}{4\\pi }}\\int _{-\\infty }^{\\infty }|f\(x\)|^{2}\\,dx\\right\)^{2}.}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a4bbb9fad9ba1f110f3ec13d91263ee0765b8a72)

The physical consequence, about the uncertainty in simultaneous position and
momentum observations of a [quantum mechanical](/wiki/Quantum_mechanical
"Quantum mechanical") system, is discussed below. The appearance of π in the
formulae of Fourier analysis is ultimately a consequence of the [Stone–von
Neumann theorem](/wiki/Stone%E2%80%93von_Neumann_theorem "Stone–von Neumann
theorem"), asserting the uniqueness of the [Schrödinger
representation](/wiki/Schr%C3%B6dinger_representation "Schrödinger
representation") of the [Heisenberg group](/wiki/Heisenberg_group "Heisenberg
group").[156]

### Gaussian integrals

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/E%5E%28-x%5E2%29.svg/220px-E%5E%28-x%5E2%29.svg.png)](/wiki/File:E%5E\(-x%5E2\).svg)

[](/wiki/File:E%5E\(-x%5E2\).svg "Enlarge")

A graph of the [Gaussian function](/wiki/Gaussian_function "Gaussian
function") _ƒ_(_x_) = _e_ − _x_ 2. The colored region between the function and
the _x_ -axis has area √π.

The fields of [probability](/wiki/Probability "Probability") and
[statistics](/wiki/Statistics "Statistics") frequently use the [normal
distribution](/wiki/Normal_distribution "Normal distribution") as a simple
model for complex phenomena; for example, scientists generally assume that the
observational error in most experiments follows a normal distribution.[157]
The [Gaussian function](/wiki/Gaussian_function "Gaussian function"), which is
the [probability density function](/wiki/Probability_density_function
"Probability density function") of the normal distribution with
[mean](/wiki/Mean "Mean") μ and [standard deviation](/wiki/Standard_deviation
"Standard deviation") σ, naturally contains π:[158]

     f ( x ) = 1 σ 2 π e − ( x − μ ) 2 / ( 2 σ 2 ) {\displaystyle f(x)={1 \over \sigma {\sqrt {2\pi }}}\,e^{-(x-\mu )^{2}/(2\sigma ^{2})}} ![f\(x\)={1 \\over \\sigma {\\sqrt {2\\pi }}}\\,e^{-\(x-\\mu \)^{2}/\(2\\sigma ^{2}\)}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/6dfc455fe10eee9f5b46e86c23b6face7127025d)

For this to be a probability density, the area under the graph of _f_ needs to
be equal to one. This follows from a [change of
variables](/wiki/Integration_by_substitution "Integration by substitution") in
the [Gaussian integral](/wiki/Gaussian_integral "Gaussian integral"):[158]

     ∫ − ∞ ∞ e − u 2 d u = π {\displaystyle \int _{-\infty }^{\infty }e^{-u^{2}}\,du={\sqrt {\pi }}} ![{\\displaystyle \\int _{-\\infty }^{\\infty }e^{-u^{2}}\\,du={\\sqrt {\\pi }}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/2a3890ce940b1efd925d23c908144db3c4049dc8)

which says that the area under the basic [bell curve](/wiki/Bell_curve "Bell
curve") in the figure is equal to the square root of π.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a5/Random_walk_simulation.png/220px-
Random_walk_simulation.png)](/wiki/File:Random_walk_simulation.png)

[](/wiki/File:Random_walk_simulation.png "Enlarge")

π [can be computed](/wiki/Arcsine_laws_\(Wiener_process\) "Arcsine laws
\(Wiener process\)") from the distribution of zeros of a one-dimensional
[Wiener process](/wiki/Wiener_process "Wiener process")

The [central limit theorem](/wiki/Central_limit_theorem "Central limit
theorem") explains the central role of normal distributions, and thus of π, in
probability and statistics. This theorem is ultimately connected with the
spectral characterization of π as the eigenvalue associated with the
Heisenberg uncertainty principle, and the fact that equality holds in the
uncertainty principle only for the Gaussian function.[159] Equivalently, π is
the unique constant making the Gaussian normal distribution _e_ -π _x_ 2 equal
to its own Fourier transform.[160] Indeed, according to Howe (1980), the
"whole business" of establishing the fundamental theorems of Fourier analysis
reduces to the Gaussian integral.
