### Topology

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Uniform_tiling_73-t2.png/220px-
Uniform_tiling_73-t2.png)](/wiki/File:Uniform_tiling_73-t2.png)

[](/wiki/File:Uniform_tiling_73-t2.png "Enlarge")

[Uniformization](/wiki/Uniformization_theorem "Uniformization theorem") of the
[Klein quartic](/wiki/Klein_quartic "Klein quartic"), a surface of
[genus](/wiki/Genus_\(mathematics\) "Genus \(mathematics\)") three and Euler
characteristic −4, as a quotient of the [hyperbolic
plane](/wiki/Poincar%C3%A9_disk_model "Poincaré disk model") by the [symmetry
group](/wiki/Symmetry_group "Symmetry group") [PSL(2,7)](/wiki/PSL\(2,7\)
"PSL\(2,7\)") of the [Fano plane](/wiki/Fano_plane "Fano plane"). The
hyperbolic area of a fundamental domain is 8π, by Gauss–Bonnet.

The constant π appears in the [Gauss–Bonnet
formula](/wiki/Gauss%E2%80%93Bonnet_formula "Gauss–Bonnet formula") which
relates the [differential geometry of
surfaces](/wiki/Differential_geometry_of_surfaces "Differential geometry of
surfaces") to their [topology](/wiki/Topology "Topology"). Specifically, if a
[compact](/wiki/Compact_space "Compact space") surface _Σ_ has [Gauss
curvature](/wiki/Gauss_curvature "Gauss curvature") _K_ , then

     ∫ Σ K d A = 2 π χ ( Σ ) {\displaystyle \int _{\Sigma }K\,dA=2\pi \chi (\Sigma )} ![{\\displaystyle \\int _{\\Sigma }K\\,dA=2\\pi \\chi \(\\Sigma \)}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/00c846ab9590f095656ecf41398c7d91b9f3a00e)

where _χ_(_Σ_) is the [Euler characteristic](/wiki/Euler_characteristic "Euler
characteristic"), which is an integer.[162] An example is the surface area of
a sphere _S_ of curvature 1 (so that its [radius of
curvature](/wiki/Radius_of_curvature "Radius of curvature"), which coincides
with its radius, is also 1.) The Euler characteristic of a sphere can be
computed from its [homology groups](/wiki/Homology_group "Homology group"),
and is found to be equal to two. Thus we have

     A ( S ) = ∫ S 1 d A = 2 π ⋅ 2 = 4 π {\displaystyle A(S)=\int _{S}1\,dA=2\pi \cdot 2=4\pi } ![{\\displaystyle A\(S\)=\\int _{S}1\\,dA=2\\pi \\cdot 2=4\\pi }](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/f541185019255fc11e6ef909d681e99b9490cf88)

reproducing the formula for the surface area of a sphere of radius 1.

The constant appears in many other integral formulae in topology, in
particular those involving [characteristic classes](/wiki/Characteristic_class
"Characteristic class") via the [Chern–Weil
homomorphism](/wiki/Chern%E2%80%93Weil_homomorphism "Chern–Weil
homomorphism").[163]

### Vector calculus

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/YL10M5sph.png/220px-
YL10M5sph.png)](/wiki/File:YL10M5sph.png)

[](/wiki/File:YL10M5sph.png "Enlarge")

The techniques of vector calculus can be understood in terms of decompositions
into [spherical harmonics](/wiki/Spherical_harmonic "Spherical harmonic")
(shown)

[Vector calculus](/wiki/Vector_calculus "Vector calculus") is a branch of
calculus that is concerned with the properties of [vector
fields](/wiki/Vector_field "Vector field"), and has many physical applications
such as to [electricity and magnetism](/wiki/Electricity_and_magnetism
"Electricity and magnetism"). The [Newtonian
potential](/wiki/Newtonian_potential "Newtonian potential") for a point source
Q situated at the origin of a three dimensional Cartesian coordinate system
is[164]

     V ( x ) = − k Q | x | {\displaystyle V(\mathbf {x} )=-{\frac {kQ}{|\mathbf {x} |}}} ![{\\displaystyle V\(\\mathbf {x} \)=-{\\frac {kQ}{|\\mathbf {x} |}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/c6604a00bc259c544995c0a7c77456c5adb65498)

which represents the [potential energy](/wiki/Potential_energy "Potential energy") of a unit mass (or charge) placed a distance |**x** | from the source, and k is a dimensional constant. The field, denoted here by **E** , which may be the (Newtonian) [gravitational field](/wiki/Gravitational_field "Gravitational field") or the (Coulomb) [electric field](/wiki/Electric_field "Electric field"), is the negative [gradient](/wiki/Gradient "Gradient") of the potential:

     E = − ∇ V . {\displaystyle \mathbf {E} =-\nabla V.} ![{\\displaystyle \\mathbf {E} =-\\nabla V.}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ada9f322050f63ee61d24edf0ed0337a9f3565a7)

Special cases include [Coulomb's law](/wiki/Coulomb%27s_law "Coulomb's law")
and [Newton's law of universal
gravitation](/wiki/Newton%27s_law_of_universal_gravitation "Newton's law of
universal gravitation"). [Gauss' law](/wiki/Gauss%27_law "Gauss' law") states
that the outward [flux](/wiki/Flux "Flux") of the field through any smooth,
simple, closed, orientable surface S containing the origin is equal to 4π _kQ_
:

     4 π k Q = {\displaystyle 4\pi kQ=} ![{\\displaystyle 4\\pi kQ=}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/30eeadbbd2d330abf8533f303c7872548421c9fe) ![\\oiint](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/OiintLaTeX.svg/25px-OiintLaTeX.svg.png) S {\displaystyle {\scriptstyle S}} ![{\\scriptstyle S}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/1dca5757c655f5ab53abd4b0d246dcfb478810e5) E ⋅ d A {\displaystyle \mathbf {E} \cdot d\mathbf {A} } ![{\\displaystyle \\mathbf {E} \\cdot d\\mathbf {A} }](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/6819dc73dff30975410eb0f586973f04e3e9a37d)

It is standard to absorb this factor of 4π into the constant k, but this
argument shows why it must appear _somewhere_. Furthermore, 4π is the surface
area of the unit sphere, but we have not assumed that S is the sphere.
However, as a consequence of the [divergence theorem](/wiki/Divergence_theorem
"Divergence theorem"), because the region away from the origin is vacuum
(source-free) it is only the [homology class](/wiki/Homology_class "Homology
class") of the surface S in **R** 3\\{0} that matters in computing the
integral, so it can be replaced by any convenient surface in the same homology
class, in particular a sphere, where spherical coordinates can be used to
calculate the integral.

A consequence of the Gauss law is that the negative
[Laplacian](/wiki/Laplacian "Laplacian") of the potential V is equal to 4π
_kQ_ times the [Dirac delta function](/wiki/Dirac_delta_function "Dirac delta
function"):

     Δ V ( x ) = − 4 π k Q δ ( x ) . {\displaystyle \Delta V(\mathbf {x} )=-4\pi kQ\delta (\mathbf {x} ).} ![{\\displaystyle \\Delta V\(\\mathbf {x} \)=-4\\pi kQ\\delta \(\\mathbf {x} \).}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/d93a81e0b60815318709f4501216f1ce544d0daa)

More general distributions of matter (or charge) are obtained from this by
[convolution](/wiki/Convolution "Convolution"), giving the [Poisson
equation](/wiki/Poisson_equation "Poisson equation")

     Δ V ( x ) = − 4 π k ρ ( x ) {\displaystyle \Delta V(\mathbf {x} )=-4\pi k\rho (\mathbf {x} )} ![{\\displaystyle \\Delta V\(\\mathbf {x} \)=-4\\pi k\\rho \(\\mathbf {x} \)}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/2d5fdc6a320a8af1912a28773730e14f8cf2b7b3)

where ρ is the distribution function.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Spacetime_lattice_analogy.svg/220px-
Spacetime_lattice_analogy.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Spacetime_lattice_analogy.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Spacetime_lattice_analogy.svg "Enlarge")

Einstein's equation states that the curvature of space-time is produced by the
matter-energy content.

The constant π also plays an analogous role in four-dimensional potentials
associated with [Einstein's equations](/wiki/Einstein%27s_equations
"Einstein's equations"), a fundamental formula which forms the basis of the
[general theory of relativity](/wiki/General_theory_of_relativity "General
theory of relativity") and describes the [fundamental
interaction](/wiki/Fundamental_interaction "Fundamental interaction") of
[gravitation](/wiki/Gravitation "Gravitation") as a result of
[spacetime](/wiki/Spacetime "Spacetime") being [curved](/wiki/Curvature
"Curvature") by [matter](/wiki/Matter "Matter") and [energy](/wiki/Energy
"Energy"):[165]

     R μ ν − 1 2 R g μ ν + Λ g μ ν = 8 π G c 4 T μ ν , {\displaystyle R_{\mu \nu }-{\frac {1}{2}}Rg_{\mu \nu }+\Lambda g_{\mu \nu }={\frac {8\pi G}{c^{4}}}T_{\mu \nu },} ![R_{\\mu \\nu }-{\\frac {1}{2}}Rg_{\\mu \\nu }+\\Lambda g_{\\mu \\nu }={\\frac {8\\pi G}{c^{4}}}T_{\\mu \\nu },](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/504a7090e837638f5c316aa2a3c1913013f06ff4)

where _R_ _μν_ is the [Ricci curvature tensor](/wiki/Ricci_curvature_tensor
"Ricci curvature tensor"), R is the [scalar curvature](/wiki/Scalar_curvature
"Scalar curvature"), _g_ _μν_ is the [metric
tensor](/wiki/Metric_tensor_\(general_relativity\) "Metric tensor \(general
relativity\)"), Λ is the [cosmological constant](/wiki/Cosmological_constant
"Cosmological constant"), G is [Newton's gravitational
constant](/wiki/Gravitational_constant "Gravitational constant"), c is the
[speed of light](/wiki/Speed_of_light "Speed of light") in vacuum, and _T_
_μν_ is the [stress–energy tensor](/wiki/Stress%E2%80%93energy_tensor
"Stress–energy tensor"). The left-hand side of Einstein's equation is a non-
linear analog of the Laplacian of the metric tensor, and reduces to that in
the weak field limit, with the  Λ g {\displaystyle \Lambda g}
![{\\displaystyle \\Lambda
g}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/0dcdc50679aaff78e6bf0ae7c45d58af26cf5c2a)
term playing the role of a [Lagrange multiplier](/wiki/Lagrange_multiplier
"Lagrange multiplier"), and the right hand side is the analog of the
distribution function, times 8π.

### Cauchy's integral formula

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Factorial05.jpg/220px-
Factorial05.jpg)](/wiki/File:Factorial05.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Factorial05.jpg "Enlarge")

Complex analytic functions can be visualized as a collection of streamlines
and equipotentials, systems of curves intersecting at right angles. Here
illustrated is the complex logarithm of the Gamma function.

One of the key tools in [complex analysis](/wiki/Complex_analysis "Complex
analysis") is [contour integration](/wiki/Contour_integration "Contour
integration") of a function over a positively oriented
([rectifiable](/wiki/Rectifiable_curve "Rectifiable curve")) [Jordan
curve](/wiki/Jordan_curve "Jordan curve") γ. A form of [Cauchy's integral
formula](/wiki/Cauchy%27s_integral_formula "Cauchy's integral formula") states
that if a point _z_ 0 is interior to γ, then[166]

     ∮ γ d z z − z 0 = 2 π i . {\displaystyle \oint _{\gamma }{\frac {dz}{z-z_{0}}}=2\pi i.} ![{\\displaystyle \\oint _{\\gamma }{\\frac {dz}{z-z_{0}}}=2\\pi i.}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/17569b627f1050cac4952724e6e56209e44dc425)

Although the curve γ is not a circle, and hence does not have any obvious
connection to the constant π, a standard proof of this result uses [Morera's
theorem](/wiki/Morera%27s_theorem "Morera's theorem"), which implies that the
integral is invariant under [homotopy](/wiki/Homotopy "Homotopy") of the
curve, so that it can be deformed to a circle and then integrated explicitly
in polar coordinates. More generally, it is true that if a rectifiable closed
curve γ does not contain _z_ 0, then the above integral is 2π _i_ times the
[winding number](/wiki/Winding_number "Winding number") of the curve.

The general form of Cauchy's integral formula establishes the relationship
between the values of a [complex analytic
function](/wiki/Complex_analytic_function "Complex analytic function")
_f_(_z_) on the Jordan curve γ and the value of _f_(_z_) at any interior point
_z_ 0 of γ:[167][168]

     ∮ γ f ( z ) z − z 0 d z = 2 π i f ( z 0 ) {\displaystyle \oint _{\gamma }{f(z) \over z-z_{0}}\,dz=2\pi if(z_{0})} ![{\\displaystyle \\oint _{\\gamma }{f\(z\) \\over z-z_{0}}\\,dz=2\\pi if\(z_{0}\)}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/f239d18251cef9208918cba90587fe2d7f618ae2)

provided _f_(_z_) is analytic in the region enclosed by γ and extends
continuously to γ. Cauchy's integral formula is a special case of the [residue
theorem](/wiki/Residue_theorem "Residue theorem"), that if _g_(_z_) is a
[meromorphic function](/wiki/Meromorphic_function "Meromorphic function") the
region enclosed by γ and is continuous in a neighborhood of γ, then

     ∮ γ g ( z ) d z = 2 π i ∑ Res ⁡ ( g , a k ) {\displaystyle \oint _{\gamma }g(z)\,dz=2\pi i\sum \operatorname {Res} (g,a_{k})} ![{\\displaystyle \\oint _{\\gamma }g\(z\)\\,dz=2\\pi i\\sum \\operatorname {Res} \(g,a_{k}\)}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/36fffa5445c67252fba1e631674f6202925ebe3a)

where the sum is of the [residues](/wiki/Residue_\(mathematics\) "Residue
\(mathematics\)") at the [poles](/wiki/Pole_\(complex_analysis\) "Pole
\(complex analysis\)") of _g_(_z_).

### The gamma function and Stirling's approximation

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Hopf_Fibration.png/220px-
Hopf_Fibration.png)](/wiki/File:Hopf_Fibration.png)

[](/wiki/File:Hopf_Fibration.png "Enlarge")

The [Hopf fibration](/wiki/Hopf_fibration "Hopf fibration") of the 3-sphere,
by [Villarceau circles](/wiki/Villarceau_circles "Villarceau circles"), over
the [complex projective line](/wiki/Complex_projective_line "Complex
projective line") with its [Fubini–Study
metric](/wiki/Fubini%E2%80%93Study_metric "Fubini–Study metric") (three
parallels are shown). The identity _S_ 3(1)/_S_ 2(1) = π/2 [is a
consequence](/wiki/Fubini%E2%80%93Study_metric#The_n_.3D_1_case "Fubini–Study
metric").

The factorial function _n_! is the product of all of the positive integers
through _n_. The [gamma function](/wiki/Gamma_function "Gamma function")
extends the concept of [factorial](/wiki/Factorial "Factorial") (normally
defined only for non-negative integers) to all complex numbers, except the
negative real integers. When the gamma function is evaluated at half-integers,
the result contains π; for example  Γ ( 1 / 2 ) = π {\displaystyle \Gamma
(1/2)={\sqrt {\pi }}} ![\\Gamma \(1/2\)={\\sqrt {\\pi
}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/75337a521eb1fcd407b39db28c38ca6f559ab3b2)
and  Γ ( 5 / 2 ) = 3 π 4 {\displaystyle \Gamma (5/2)={\frac {3{\sqrt {\pi
}}}{4}}} ![\\Gamma \(5/2\)={\\frac {3{\\sqrt {\\pi
}}}{4}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/f77e555672bd3e01395a2b5da42d6ef5b7f62ff8).[169]

The gamma function is defined by its [Weierstrass
product](/wiki/Weierstrass_product "Weierstrass product") development:[170]

     Γ ( z ) = e − γ z ∏ n = 1 ∞ e z / n 1 + z / n {\displaystyle \Gamma (z)=e^{-\gamma z}\prod _{n=1}^{\infty }{\frac {e^{z/n}}{1+z/n}}} ![{\\displaystyle \\Gamma \(z\)=e^{-\\gamma z}\\prod _{n=1}^{\\infty }{\\frac {e^{z/n}}{1+z/n}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/e2177df75db917fd41fc4bce89f83ad7b33452ac)

where γ is the [Euler–Mascheroni
constant](/wiki/Euler%E2%80%93Mascheroni_constant "Euler–Mascheroni
constant"). Evaluated at _z_ = 1/2 and squared, the equation Γ(1/2)2 = π
reduces to the Wallis product formula. The gamma function is also connected to
the [Riemann zeta function](/wiki/Riemann_zeta_function "Riemann zeta
function") and identities for the [functional
determinant](/wiki/Functional_determinant "Functional determinant"), in which
the constant π plays an important role.

The gamma function is used to calculate the volume _V_ _n_(_r_) of the [_n_
-dimensional ball](/wiki/N-ball "N-ball") of radius _r_ in Euclidean _n_
-dimensional space, and the surface area _S_ _n_ −1(_r_) of its boundary, the
[(_n_ −1)-dimensional sphere](/wiki/N-sphere "N-sphere"):[171]

     V n ( r ) = π n / 2 Γ ( n 2 + 1 ) r n {\displaystyle V_{n}(r)={\frac {\pi ^{n/2}}{\Gamma ({\frac {n}{2}}+1)}}r^{n}} ![V_{n}\(r\)={\\frac {\\pi ^{n/2}}{\\Gamma \({\\frac {n}{2}}+1\)}}r^{n}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/7eafc01d626925a7b8b9a9ac4b0e01f52047bc32)

     S n − 1 ( r ) = n π n / 2 Γ ( n 2 + 1 ) r n − 1 {\displaystyle S_{n-1}(r)={\frac {n\pi ^{n/2}}{\Gamma ({\frac {n}{2}}+1)}}r^{n-1}} ![{\\displaystyle S_{n-1}\(r\)={\\frac {n\\pi ^{n/2}}{\\Gamma \({\\frac {n}{2}}+1\)}}r^{n-1}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/6de01ea688d58656964869847aa1942b92e9bed0)

Further, it follows from the [functional equation](/wiki/Functional_equation
"Functional equation") that

     2 π r = S n + 1 ( r ) V n ( r ) . {\displaystyle 2\pi r={\frac {S_{n+1}(r)}{V_{n}(r)}}.} ![{\\displaystyle 2\\pi r={\\frac {S_{n+1}\(r\)}{V_{n}\(r\)}}.}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/807a85f4bb84937de20521b0db1fc83295a48532)

The gamma function can be used to create a simple approximation to the
factorial function _n_! for large _n_ :  n ! ∼ 2 π n ( n e ) n {\displaystyle
n!\sim {\sqrt {2\pi n}}\left({\frac {n}{e}}\right)^{n}} ![n!\\sim {\\sqrt
{2\\pi n}}\\left\({\\frac
{n}{e}}\\right\)^{n}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/977732acd9d1c6bbe89c54fc956f3c16d2feade9)
which is known as [Stirling's approximation](/wiki/Stirling%27s_approximation
"Stirling's approximation").[172] Equivalently,

     π = lim n → ∞ e 2 n n ! 2 2 n 2 n + 1 . {\displaystyle \pi =\lim _{n\to \infty }{\frac {e^{2n}n!^{2}}{2n^{2n+1}}}.} ![{\\displaystyle \\pi =\\lim _{n\\to \\infty }{\\frac {e^{2n}n!^{2}}{2n^{2n+1}}}.}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/04bedea644b29f119cf4d2175576c12d61010d01)

As a geometrical application of Stirling's approximation, let Δ _n_ denote the
[standard simplex](/wiki/Simplex "Simplex") in _n_ -dimensional Euclidean
space, and (_n_ \+ 1)Δ _n_ denote the simplex having all of its sides scaled
up by a factor of _n_ \+ 1. Then

     Vol ⁡ ( ( n + 1 ) Δ n ) = ( n + 1 ) n n ! ∼ e n + 1 2 π n . {\displaystyle \operatorname {Vol} ((n+1)\Delta _{n})={\frac {(n+1)^{n}}{n!}}\sim {\frac {e^{n+1}}{\sqrt {2\pi n}}}.} ![{\\displaystyle \\operatorname {Vol} \(\(n+1\)\\Delta _{n}\)={\\frac {\(n+1\)^{n}}{n!}}\\sim {\\frac {e^{n+1}}{\\sqrt {2\\pi n}}}.}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/fae31c667990be5b0307c3ab5233509497d33bac)

[Ehrhart's volume conjecture](/wiki/Ehrhart%27s_volume_conjecture "Ehrhart's
volume conjecture") is that this is the (optimal) upper bound on the volume of
a [convex body](/wiki/Convex_body "Convex body") containing only one [lattice
point](/wiki/Lattice_point "Lattice point").[173]

### Number theory and Riemann zeta function

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Pr%C3%BCfer.png/220px-
Pr%C3%BCfer.png)](/wiki/File:Pr%C3%BCfer.png)

[](/wiki/File:Pr%C3%BCfer.png "Enlarge")

Each prime has an associated [Prüfer group](/wiki/Pr%C3%BCfer_group "Prüfer
group"), which are arithmetic localizations of the circle. The
[L-functions](/wiki/L-function "L-function") of analytic number theory are
also localized in each prime _p_.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/ModularGroup-
FundamentalDomain.svg/220px-ModularGroup-
FundamentalDomain.svg.png)](/wiki/File:ModularGroup-FundamentalDomain.svg)

[](/wiki/File:ModularGroup-FundamentalDomain.svg "Enlarge")

Solution of the Basel problem using the [Weil
conjecture](/wiki/Weil_conjecture_on_Tamagawa_numbers "Weil conjecture on
Tamagawa numbers"): the value of  ζ ( 2 ) {\displaystyle \zeta (2)} ![\\zeta
\(2\)](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/eff246e5aba5259593186618c576a3b7e14bc3c8)
is the [hyperbolic](/wiki/Poincar%C3%A9_half-plane_model "Poincaré half-plane
model") area of a fundamental domain of the [modular
group](/wiki/Modular_group "Modular group"), times  2 π {\displaystyle 2\pi }
![2\\pi
](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/73efd1f6493490b058097060a572606d2c550a06)

The [Riemann zeta function](/wiki/Riemann_zeta_function "Riemann zeta
function") _ζ_(_s_) is used in many areas of mathematics. When evaluated at
_s_ = 2 it can be written as

     ζ ( 2 ) = 1 1 2 + 1 2 2 + 1 3 2 + ⋯ {\displaystyle \zeta (2)={\frac {1}{1^{2}}}+{\frac {1}{2^{2}}}+{\frac {1}{3^{2}}}+\cdots } ![\\zeta \(2\)={\\frac {1}{1^{2}}}+{\\frac {1}{2^{2}}}+{\\frac {1}{3^{2}}}+\\cdots ](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/581714c279e80acf87edfb221004f575d4770e97)

Finding a [simple solution](/wiki/Closed-form_expression "Closed-form
expression") for this infinite series was a famous problem in mathematics
called the [Basel problem](/wiki/Basel_problem "Basel problem"). [Leonhard
Euler](/wiki/Leonhard_Euler "Leonhard Euler") solved it in 1735 when he showed
it was equal to π2/6.[86] Euler's result leads to the [number
theory](/wiki/Number_theory "Number theory") result that the probability of
two random numbers being [relatively prime](/wiki/Relatively_prime "Relatively
prime") (that is, having no shared factors) is equal to 6/π2.[174][175] This
probability is based on the observation that the probability that any number
is [divisible](/wiki/Divisible "Divisible") by a prime _p_ is 1/_p_ (for
example, every 7th integer is divisible by 7.) Hence the probability that two
numbers are both divisible by this prime is 1/_p_ 2, and the probability that
at least one of them is not is 1 − 1/_p_ 2. For distinct primes, these
divisibility events are mutually independent; so the probability that two
numbers are relatively prime is given by a product over all primes:[176]

     ∏ p ∞ ( 1 − 1 p 2 ) = ( ∏ p ∞ 1 1 − p − 2 ) − 1 = 1 1 + 1 2 2 + 1 3 2 + ⋯ = 1 ζ ( 2 ) = 6 π 2 ≈ 61 % . {\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}\prod _{p}^{\infty }\left(1-{\frac {1}{p^{2}}}\right)&=\left(\prod _{p}^{\infty }{\frac {1}{1-p^{-2}}}\right)^{-1}\\\\[4pt]&={\frac {1}{1+{\frac {1}{2^{2}}}+{\frac {1}{3^{2}}}+\cdots }}\\\\[4pt]&={\frac {1}{\zeta (2)}}={\frac {6}{\pi ^{2}}}\approx 61\%.\end{aligned}}} ![{\\displaystyle {\\begin{aligned}\\prod _{p}^{\\infty }\\left\(1-{\\frac {1}{p^{2}}}\\right\)&=\\left\(\\prod _{p}^{\\infty }{\\frac {1}{1-p^{-2}}}\\right\)^{-1}\\\\\[4pt\]&={\\frac {1}{1+{\\frac {1}{2^{2}}}+{\\frac {1}{3^{2}}}+\\cdots }}\\\\\[4pt\]&={\\frac {1}{\\zeta \(2\)}}={\\frac {6}{\\pi ^{2}}}\\approx 61\\%.\\end{aligned}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/33ad11b6609d91487577949c7a42872afdc33a36)

This probability can be used in conjunction with a [random number
generator](/wiki/Random_number_generator "Random number generator") to
approximate π using a Monte Carlo approach.[177]

The solution to the Basel problem implies that the geometrically derived
quantity π is connected in a deep way to the distribution of prime numbers.
This is a special case of [Weil's conjecture on Tamagawa
numbers](/wiki/Weil%27s_conjecture_on_Tamagawa_numbers "Weil's conjecture on
Tamagawa numbers"), which asserts the equality of similar such infinite
products of _arithmetic_ quantities, localized at each prime _p_ , and a
_geometrical_ quantity: the reciprocal of the volume of a certain [locally
symmetric space](/wiki/Locally_symmetric_space "Locally symmetric space"). In
the case of the Basel problem, it is the [hyperbolic
3-manifold](/wiki/Hyperbolic_3-manifold "Hyperbolic 3-manifold")
[SL2(**R**)](/wiki/SL2\(R\) "SL2\(R\)")/[SL2(**Z**)](/wiki/Modular_group
"Modular group").[178]

The zeta function also satisfies Riemann's functional equation, which involves
π as well as the gamma function:

     ζ ( s ) = 2 s π s − 1 sin ⁡ ( π s 2 ) Γ ( 1 − s ) ζ ( 1 − s ) . {\displaystyle \zeta (s)=2^{s}\pi ^{s-1}\ \sin \left({\frac {\pi s}{2}}\right)\ \Gamma (1-s)\ \zeta (1-s)\\!.} ![{\\displaystyle \\zeta \(s\)=2^{s}\\pi ^{s-1}\\ \\sin \\left\({\\frac {\\pi s}{2}}\\right\)\\ \\Gamma \(1-s\)\\ \\zeta \(1-s\)\\!.}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/3876b4344ddc1ce9ec66198c2f963cf34c28a5db)

Furthermore, the derivative of the zeta function satisfies

     exp ⁡ ( − ζ ′ ( 0 ) ) = 2 π . {\displaystyle \exp(-\zeta '(0))={\sqrt {2\pi }}.} ![{\\displaystyle \\exp\(-\\zeta '\(0\)\)={\\sqrt {2\\pi }}.}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/d2907a3d1a8927b4fd2a276f0463569cc1f77b6f)

A consequence is that π can be obtained from the [functional
determinant](/wiki/Functional_determinant "Functional determinant") of the
[harmonic oscillator](/wiki/Harmonic_oscillator "Harmonic oscillator"). This
functional determinant can be computed via a product expansion, and is
equivalent to the Wallis product formula.[179] The calculation can be recast
in [quantum mechanics](/wiki/Quantum_mechanics "Quantum mechanics"),
specifically the [variational approach](/wiki/Calculus_of_variations "Calculus
of variations") to the [spectrum of the hydrogen atom](/wiki/Bohr_model "Bohr
model").[180]

### Fourier series

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/2-adic_integers_with_dual_colorings.svg/220px-2-adic_integers_with_dual_colorings.svg.png)](/wiki/File:2-adic_integers_with_dual_colorings.svg)

[](/wiki/File:2-adic_integers_with_dual_colorings.svg "Enlarge")

π appears in characters of [p-adic numbers](/wiki/P-adic_numbers "P-adic
numbers") (shown), which are elements of a [Prüfer
group](/wiki/Pr%C3%BCfer_group "Prüfer group"). [Tate's
thesis](/wiki/Tate%27s_thesis "Tate's thesis") makes heavy use of this
machinery.[181]

The constant π also appears naturally in [Fourier series](/wiki/Fourier_series
"Fourier series") of [periodic functions](/wiki/Periodic_function "Periodic
function"). Periodic functions are functions on the group **T** =**R** /**Z**
of fractional parts of real numbers. The Fourier decomposition shows that a
complex-valued function _f_ on **T** can be written as an infinite linear
superposition of [unitary characters](/wiki/Unitary_character "Unitary
character") of **T**. That is, continuous [group
homomorphisms](/wiki/Group_homomorphism "Group homomorphism") from **T** to
the [circle group](/wiki/Circle_group "Circle group") _U_(1) of unit modulus
complex numbers. It is a theorem that every character of **T** is one of the
complex exponentials  e n ( x ) = e 2 π i n x {\displaystyle e_{n}(x)=e^{2\pi
inx}} ![{\\displaystyle e_{n}\(x\)=e^{2\\pi
inx}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/142bcbcd2610f5640cdfd50166a105624164d007).

There is a unique character on **T** , up to complex conjugation, that is a
group isomorphism. Using the [Haar measure](/wiki/Haar_measure "Haar measure")
on the circle group, the constant π is half the magnitude of the
[Radon–Nikodym derivative](/wiki/Radon%E2%80%93Nikodym_derivative
"Radon–Nikodym derivative") of this character. The other characters have
derivatives whose magnitudes are positive integral multiples of 2π.[18] As a
result, the constant π is the unique number such that the group **T** ,
equipped with its Haar measure, is [Pontrjagin dual](/wiki/Pontrjagin_dual
"Pontrjagin dual") to the [lattice](/wiki/Lattice_\(group\) "Lattice
\(group\)") of integral multiples of 2π.[182] This is a version of the one-
dimensional [Poisson summation formula](/wiki/Poisson_summation_formula
"Poisson summation formula").

### Modular forms and theta functions

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/ca/Lattice_with_tau.svg/220px-
Lattice_with_tau.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Lattice_with_tau.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Lattice_with_tau.svg "Enlarge")

Theta functions transform under the [lattice](/wiki/Lattice_\(group\) "Lattice
\(group\)") of periods of an elliptic curve.

The constant π is connected in a deep way with the theory of [modular
forms](/wiki/Modular_form "Modular form") and [theta
functions](/wiki/Theta_function "Theta function"). For example, the
[Chudnovsky algorithm](/wiki/Chudnovsky_algorithm "Chudnovsky algorithm")
involves in an essential way the [j-invariant](/wiki/J-invariant
"J-invariant") of an [elliptic curve](/wiki/Elliptic_curve "Elliptic curve").

[Modular forms](/wiki/Modular_form "Modular form") are [holomorphic
functions](/wiki/Holomorphic_function "Holomorphic function") in the [upper
half plane](/wiki/Upper_half_plane "Upper half plane") characterized by their
transformation properties under the [modular group](/wiki/Modular_group
"Modular group") S L 2 ( Z ) {\displaystyle \mathrm {SL} _{2}(\mathbb {Z} )}
![{\\displaystyle \\mathrm {SL} _{2}\(\\mathbb {Z}
\)}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ca2d95ba975aa85bd6c46f0a696872d3aa385869)
(or its various subgroups), a lattice in the group  S L 2 ( R ) {\displaystyle
\mathrm {SL} _{2}(\mathbb {R} )} ![{\\displaystyle \\mathrm {SL}
_{2}\(\\mathbb {R}
\)}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/0bb95adfe7c34f38de771bb5fa44e17ec26deeee).
An example is the [Jacobi theta function](/wiki/Jacobi_theta_function "Jacobi
theta function")

     θ ( z , τ ) = ∑ n = − ∞ ∞ e 2 π i n z + i π n 2 τ {\displaystyle \theta (z,\tau )=\sum _{n=-\infty }^{\infty }e^{2\pi inz+i\pi n^{2}\tau }} ![{\\displaystyle \\theta \(z,\\tau \)=\\sum _{n=-\\infty }^{\\infty }e^{2\\pi inz+i\\pi n^{2}\\tau }}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/26b78016061583b9c6d988f35dfdb5fac22effd1)

which is a kind of modular form called a [Jacobi form](/wiki/Jacobi_form
"Jacobi form").[183] This is sometimes written in terms of the
[nome](/wiki/Nome_\(mathematics\) "Nome \(mathematics\)") q = e π i τ
{\displaystyle q=e^{\pi i\tau }} ![q=e^{\\pi i
\\tau}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/b04b5fc2797318028727bd06733bb52300c99e9b).

The constant π is the unique constant making the Jacobi theta function an
[automorphic form](/wiki/Automorphic_form "Automorphic form"), which means
that it transforms in a specific way. Certain identities hold for all
automorphic forms. An example is

     θ ( z + τ , τ ) = e − π i τ − 2 π i z θ ( z , τ ) , {\displaystyle \theta (z+\tau ,\tau )=e^{-\pi i\tau -2\pi iz}\theta (z,\tau ),} ![{\\displaystyle \\theta \(z+\\tau ,\\tau \)=e^{-\\pi i\\tau -2\\pi iz}\\theta \(z,\\tau \),}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/94df3eda20c1a72c699a40cf8b4e0ef49801f601)

which implies that θ transforms as a representation under the discrete
[Heisenberg group](/wiki/Heisenberg_group "Heisenberg group"). General modular
forms and other [theta functions](/wiki/Theta_function "Theta function") also
involve π, once again because of the [Stone–von Neumann
theorem](/wiki/Stone%E2%80%93von_Neumann_theorem "Stone–von Neumann
theorem").[183]

### Cauchy distribution and potential theory

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Witch_of_Agnesi%2C_construction.svg/220px-
Witch_of_Agnesi%2C_construction.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Witch_of_Agnesi,_construction.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Witch_of_Agnesi,_construction.svg "Enlarge")

The [Witch of Agnesi](/wiki/Witch_of_Agnesi "Witch of Agnesi"), named for
[Maria Agnesi](/wiki/Maria_Gaetana_Agnesi "Maria Gaetana Agnesi") (1718–1799),
is a geometrical construction of the graph of the Cauchy distribution.

The [Cauchy distribution](/wiki/Cauchy_distribution "Cauchy distribution")

     g ( x ) = 1 π ⋅ 1 x 2 + 1 {\displaystyle g(x)={\frac {1}{\pi }}\cdot {\frac {1}{x^{2}+1}}} ![{\\displaystyle g\(x\)={\\frac {1}{\\pi }}\\cdot {\\frac {1}{x^{2}+1}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/19fbbd1733585d1552298a9352029f90887c23a8)

is a [probability density function](/wiki/Probability_density_function
"Probability density function"). The total probability is equal to one, owing
to the integral:

     ∫ − ∞ ∞ 1 x 2 + 1 d x = π . {\displaystyle \int _{-\infty }^{\infty }{\frac {1}{x^{2}+1}}\,dx=\pi .} ![\\int _{-\\infty }^{\\infty }{\\frac {1}{x^{2}+1}}\\,dx=\\pi .](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/c1f17dafb3b274d126111151564a8666bb4ac93a)

The [Shannon entropy](/wiki/Shannon_entropy "Shannon entropy") of the Cauchy
distribution is equal to log(4π), which also involves π.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/5a/Brownianmotion_beads_in_water_spim_video.gif)](/wiki/File:Brownianmotion_beads_in_water_spim_video.gif)

[](/wiki/File:Brownianmotion_beads_in_water_spim_video.gif "Enlarge")

The Cauchy distribution governs the passage of [Brownian
particles](/wiki/Brownian_motion "Brownian motion") through a membrane.

The Cauchy distribution plays an important role in [potential
theory](/wiki/Potential_theory "Potential theory") because it is the simplest
[Furstenberg measure](/wiki/Furstenberg_boundary "Furstenberg boundary"), the
classical [Poisson kernel](/wiki/Poisson_kernel "Poisson kernel") associated
with a [Brownian motion](/wiki/Brownian_motion "Brownian motion") in a half-
plane.[184] [Conjugate harmonic functions](/wiki/Conjugate_harmonic_function
"Conjugate harmonic function") and so also the [Hilbert
transform](/wiki/Hilbert_transform "Hilbert transform") are associated with
the asymptotics of the Poisson kernel. The Hilbert transform _H_ is the
integral transform given by the [Cauchy principal
value](/wiki/Cauchy_principal_value "Cauchy principal value") of the [singular
integral](/wiki/Singular_integral "Singular integral")

     H f ( t ) = 1 π ∫ − ∞ ∞ f ( x ) d x x − t . {\displaystyle Hf(t)={\frac {1}{\pi }}\int _{-\infty }^{\infty }{\frac {f(x)\,dx}{x-t}}.} ![{\\displaystyle Hf\(t\)={\\frac {1}{\\pi }}\\int _{-\\infty }^{\\infty }{\\frac {f\(x\)\\,dx}{x-t}}.}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/2cd815ba69c72a4cb8e65180491f6db68eda5a12)

The constant π is the unique (positive) normalizing factor such that _H_
defines a [linear complex structure](/wiki/Linear_complex_structure "Linear
complex structure") on the Hilbert space of square-integrable real-valued
functions on the real line.[185] The Hilbert transform, like the Fourier
transform, can be characterized purely in terms of its transformation
properties on the Hilbert space L2(**R**): up to a normalization factor, it is
the unique bounded linear operator that commutes with positive dilations and
anticommutes with all reflections of the real line.[186] The constant π is the
unique normalizing factor that makes this transformation unitary.

### Complex dynamics

[![An complex black shape on a blue
background.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Mandel_zoom_00_mandelbrot_set.jpg/220px-
Mandel_zoom_00_mandelbrot_set.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mandel_zoom_00_mandelbrot_set.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mandel_zoom_00_mandelbrot_set.jpg "Enlarge")

π can be computed from the [Mandelbrot set](/wiki/Mandelbrot_set "Mandelbrot
set"), by counting the number of iterations required before point (−0.75, ε)
diverges.

An occurrence of π in the [Mandelbrot set](/wiki/Mandelbrot_set "Mandelbrot
set") [fractal](/wiki/Fractal "Fractal") was discovered by David Boll in
1991.[187] He examined the behavior of the Mandelbrot set near the "neck" at
(−0.75, 0). If points with coordinates (−0.75, ε) are considered, as ε tends
to zero, the number of iterations until divergence for the point multiplied by
ε converges to π. The point (0.25, ε) at the cusp of the large "valley" on the
right side of the Mandelbrot set behaves similarly: the number of iterations
until divergence multiplied by the square root of ε tends to π.[187][188]

## Outside mathematics

### Describing physical phenomena

Although not a [physical constant](/wiki/Physical_constant "Physical
constant"), π appears routinely in equations describing fundamental principles
of the universe, often because of π's relationship to the circle and to
[spherical coordinate systems](/wiki/Spherical_coordinate_system "Spherical
coordinate system"). A simple formula from the field of [classical
mechanics](/wiki/Classical_mechanics "Classical mechanics") gives the
approximate period _T_ of a simple [pendulum](/wiki/Pendulum "Pendulum") of
length _L_ , swinging with a small amplitude (_g_ is the [earth's
gravitational acceleration](/wiki/Gravity_of_Earth "Gravity of Earth")):[189]

     T ≈ 2 π L g . {\displaystyle T\approx 2\pi {\sqrt {\frac {L}{g}}}.} ![T\\approx 2\\pi {\\sqrt {\\frac {L}{g}}}.](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/bd035c36f4530cfdbe4d650dad9a9fb96600c271)

One of the key formulae of [quantum mechanics](/wiki/Quantum_mechanics
"Quantum mechanics") is [Heisenberg's uncertainty
principle](/wiki/Heisenberg%27s_uncertainty_principle "Heisenberg's
uncertainty principle"), which shows that the uncertainty in the measurement
of a particle's position (Δ _x_) and [momentum](/wiki/Momentum "Momentum") (Δ
_p_) cannot both be arbitrarily small at the same time (where _h_ is [Planck's
constant](/wiki/Planck%27s_constant "Planck's constant")):[190]

     Δ x Δ p ≥ h 4 π . {\displaystyle \Delta x\,\Delta p\geq {\frac {h}{4\pi }}.} ![\\Delta x\\,\\Delta p\\geq {\\frac {h}{4\\pi }}.](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/f2897ef997b77cd45b82bf7f217d4a614fefdbfa)

The fact that π is approximately equal to 3 plays a role in the relatively
long lifetime of [orthopositronium](/wiki/Orthopositronium
"Orthopositronium"). The inverse lifetime to lowest order in the [fine-
structure constant](/wiki/Fine-structure_constant "Fine-structure constant")
_α_ is[191]

     1 τ = 2 π 2 − 9 9 π m α 6 , {\displaystyle {\frac {1}{\tau }}=2{\frac {\pi ^{2}-9}{9\pi }}m\alpha ^{6},} ![{\\frac {1}{\\tau }}=2{\\frac {\\pi ^{2}-9}{9\\pi }}m\\alpha ^{6},](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/cbb56ed1dcfe3f400120917777abf6e806bb364d)

where _m_ is the mass of the electron.

π is present in some structural engineering formulae, such as the
[buckling](/wiki/Buckling "Buckling") formula derived by Euler, which gives
the maximum axial load _F_ that a long, slender column of length _L_ ,
[modulus of elasticity](/wiki/Modulus_of_elasticity "Modulus of elasticity")
_E_ , and [area moment of inertia](/wiki/Area_moment_of_inertia "Area moment
of inertia") _I_ can carry without buckling:[192]

     F = π 2 E I L 2 . {\displaystyle F={\frac {\pi ^{2}EI}{L^{2}}}.} ![F={\\frac {\\pi ^{2}EI}{L^{2}}}.](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/94ec2b531f168b03efdfcdfd27061df942e2a4c4)

The field of [fluid dynamics](/wiki/Fluid_dynamics "Fluid dynamics") contains
π in [Stokes' law](/wiki/Stokes%27_law "Stokes' law"), which approximates the
[frictional force](/wiki/Drag_force "Drag force") _F_ exerted on small,
[spherical](/wiki/Sphere "Sphere") objects of radius _R_ , moving with
velocity _v_ in a [fluid](/wiki/Fluid "Fluid") with [dynamic
viscosity](/wiki/Dynamic_viscosity "Dynamic viscosity") _η_ :[193]

     F = 6 π η R v . {\displaystyle F=6\,\pi \,\eta \,R\,v.} ![F=6\\,\\pi \\,\\eta \\,R\\,v.](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/56fa1c87a5fa2e77f6f0705a882182b2a41d846e)

Under ideal conditions (uniform gentle slope on a homogeneously erodible
substrate), the [sinuosity](/wiki/Sinuosity "Sinuosity") of a
[meandering](/wiki/Meander "Meander") river approaches π. The sinuosity is the
ratio between the actual length and the straight-line distance from source to
mouth. Faster currents along the outside edges of a river's bends cause more
erosion than along the inside edges, thus pushing the bends even farther out,
and increasing the overall loopiness of the river. However, that loopiness
eventually causes the river to double back on itself in places and "short-
circuit", creating an [ox-bow lake](/wiki/Ox-bow_lake "Ox-bow lake") in the
process. The balance between these two opposing factors leads to an average
ratio of π between the actual length and the direct distance between source
and mouth.[194][195]

### Memorizing digits

Main article: [Piphilology](/wiki/Piphilology "Piphilology")

[Piphilology](/wiki/Piphilology "Piphilology") is the practice of memorizing
large numbers of digits of π,[196] and world-records are kept by the
_[Guinness World Records](/wiki/Guinness_World_Records "Guinness World
Records")_. The record for memorizing digits of π, certified by Guinness World
Records, is 70,000 digits, recited in India by Rajveer Meena in 9 hours and 27
minutes on 21 March 2015.[197] In 2006, [Akira
Haraguchi](/wiki/Akira_Haraguchi "Akira Haraguchi"), a retired Japanese
engineer, claimed to have recited 100,000 decimal places, but the claim was
not verified by Guinness World Records.[198]

One common technique is to memorize a story or poem in which the word lengths
represent the digits of π: The first word has three letters, the second word
has one, the third has four, the fourth has one, the fifth has five, and so
on. An early example of a memorization aid, originally devised by English
scientist [James Jeans](/wiki/James_Hopwood_Jeans "James Hopwood Jeans"), is
"How I want a drink, alcoholic of course, after the heavy lectures involving
quantum mechanics."[196] When a poem is used, it is sometimes referred to as a
_piem_. Poems for memorizing π have been composed in several languages in
addition to English.[196] Record-setting π memorizers typically do not rely on
poems, but instead use methods such as remembering number patterns and the
[method of loci](/wiki/Method_of_loci "Method of loci").[199]

A few authors have used the digits of π to establish a new form of
[constrained writing](/wiki/Constrained_writing "Constrained writing"), where
the word lengths are required to represent the digits of π. The _[Cadaeic
Cadenza](/wiki/Cadaeic_Cadenza "Cadaeic Cadenza")_ contains the first 3835
digits of π in this manner,[200] and the full-length book _Not a Wake_
contains 10,000 words, each representing one digit of π.[201]

### In popular culture

[![Pi Pie at Delft
University](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Pi_pie2.jpg/220px-
Pi_pie2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Pi_pie2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Pi_pie2.jpg "Enlarge")

A pi pie. The circular shape of [pie](/wiki/Pie "Pie") makes it a frequent
subject of pi [puns](/wiki/Pun "Pun").

Perhaps because of the simplicity of its definition and its ubiquitous
presence in formulae, π has been represented in popular culture more than
other mathematical constructs.[202]

In the 2008 [Open University](/wiki/Open_University "Open University") and
[BBC](/wiki/BBC "BBC") documentary co-production, _[The Story of
Maths](/wiki/The_Story_of_Maths "The Story of Maths")_ , aired in October 2008
on [BBC Four](/wiki/BBC_Four "BBC Four"), British mathematician [Marcus du
Sautoy](/wiki/Marcus_du_Sautoy "Marcus du Sautoy") shows a
[visualization](/wiki/Information_graphics "Information graphics") of the –
historically first exact – [formula for calculating
π](/wiki/Madhava_of_Sangamagrama#The_value_of_.CF.80_.28pi.29 "Madhava of
Sangamagrama") when visiting India and exploring its contributions to
trigonometry.[203]

In the [Palais de la Découverte](/wiki/Palais_de_la_D%C3%A9couverte "Palais de
la Découverte") (a science museum in Paris) there is a circular room known as
the _pi room_. On its wall are inscribed 707 digits of π. The digits are large
wooden characters attached to the dome-like ceiling. The digits were based on
an 1853 calculation by English mathematician [William
Shanks](/wiki/William_Shanks "William Shanks"), which included an error
beginning at the 528th digit. The error was detected in 1946 and corrected in
1949.[204]

In [Carl Sagan](/wiki/Carl_Sagan "Carl Sagan")'s novel
_[Contact](/wiki/Contact_\(novel\) "Contact \(novel\)")_ it is suggested that
the creator of the universe buried a message deep within the digits of π.[205]
The digits of π have also been incorporated into the lyrics of the song "Pi"
from the album _[Aerial](/wiki/Aerial_\(album\) "Aerial \(album\)")_ by [Kate
Bush](/wiki/Kate_Bush "Kate Bush").[206]

In the United States, [Pi Day](/wiki/Pi_Day "Pi Day") falls on 14 March
(written 3/14 in the US style), and is popular among students.[207] π and its
digital representation are often used by self-described "math
[geeks](/wiki/Geek "Geek")" for [inside jokes](/wiki/Inside_joke "Inside
joke") among mathematically and technologically minded groups. Several college
[cheers](/wiki/Cheering "Cheering") at the [Massachusetts Institute of
Technology](/wiki/Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology "Massachusetts
Institute of Technology") include "3.14159".[208] Pi Day in 2015 was
particularly significant because the date and time 3/14/15 9:26:53 reflected
many more digits of pi.[209]

During the 2011 auction for [Nortel](/wiki/Nortel "Nortel")'s portfolio of
valuable technology patents, [Google](/wiki/Google "Google") made a series of
unusually specific bids based on mathematical and scientific constants,
including π.[210]

In 1958 [Albert Eagle](/wiki/Albert_Eagle "Albert Eagle")
[proposed](/wiki/Turn_\(geometry\)#Tau_proposal "Turn \(geometry\)") replacing
π by τ ([tau](/wiki/Tau "Tau")), where τ = π/2, to simplify formulas.[211]
However, no other authors are known to use τ in this way. Some people use a
different value, τ = 6.283185... = 2π,[212] arguing that τ, as the number of
radians in one [turn](/wiki/Turn_\(geometry\) "Turn \(geometry\)") or as the
ratio of a circle's circumference to its radius rather than its diameter, is
more natural than π and simplifies many formulas.[213][214] Celebrations of
this number, because it approximately equals 6.28, by making 28 June "Tau Day"
and eating "twice the pie",[215] have been reported in the media. However,
this use of τ has not made its way into mainstream mathematics.[216]

In 1897, an amateur American mathematician attempted to persuade the [Indiana
legislature](/wiki/Indiana_General_Assembly "Indiana General Assembly") to
pass the [Indiana Pi Bill](/wiki/Indiana_Pi_Bill "Indiana Pi Bill"), which
described a method to [square the circle](/wiki/Squaring_the_circle "Squaring
the circle") and contained text that implied various incorrect values for π,
including 3.2. The bill is notorious as an attempt to establish a value of
scientific constant by legislative fiat. The bill was passed by the Indiana
House of Representatives, but rejected by the Senate, meaning it did not
become a law.[217]

### In computer culture

In contemporary [internet culture](/wiki/Internet_culture "Internet culture"),
individuals and organizations frequently pay homage to the number π. For
instance, the [computer scientist](/wiki/Computer_scientist "Computer
scientist") [Donald Knuth](/wiki/Donald_Knuth "Donald Knuth") let the version
numbers of his program [TeX](/wiki/TeX "TeX") approach π. The versions are 3,
3.1, 3.14, and so forth.[218]
